Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WJC-NNH1-JDH1-C4RY-00000-00Trump shows love-hate for social media2019-07-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:08ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. B8Trump shows love-hate for social mediaKevin Freking and Marcy Gordon The Associated Press

U.S. President Donald Trump, who has weaponized social media to eviscerate opponents and promote himself, was convening a White House conference Thursday of like-minded critics of Big Tech, notably excluding representatives from the very platforms he exploits.

The meeting represented an escalation of his battle with companies like Facebook, Google and even his preferred communications outlet, Twitter. The president has claimed, without evidence, that the companies are "against me" and even suggested U.S. regulators should sue them on grounds of anti-conservative bias.

The high-profile White House event raised the prospect of Trump using the forum to signal tough actions ahead by his administration against Big Tech in the areas of competition and privacy.

The firms already are under closer scrutiny than ever by regulators following a stream of scandals, including Facebook's lapses opening the personal data of millions of users to Trump's 2016 campaign. A bipartisan push for new data privacy legislation has emerged in Congress. Regulators at the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission are pursuing antitrust investigations of Facebook, Google, Apple and Amazon.

Trump's volley of Twitter messages Thursday had familiar targets - "certain companies," the media and his Democratic rivals - that have resonance with his political base. The president predicted, without foundation, the demise of the media and the social media platforms if he loses to a Democrat in 2020. He hailed himself as "so great looking and smart, a true Stable Genius!"

A "big subject" of the summit would be "the tremendous dishonesty, bias, discrimination and suppression practiced by certain companies," Trump said in his tweets.

Among the conservative organizations expected to participate in the White House meeting are Turning Point USA, a nonprofit; and the Heritage Foundation, a Washington think-tank.

urn:contentItem:5WJB-SHB1-F091-R069-00000-00Trump shows love-hate for social media as he leads 'summit'2019-07-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:08ZLexisNexisPg. 8Trump shows love-hate for social media as he leads 'summit'

US PRESIDENT Donald Trump, who has weaponised social media to eviscerate opponents and promote himself, was convening a White House conference yesterday of like-minded critics of Big Tech, notably excluding representatives from the very platforms he exploits.

The meeting represented an escalation of his battle with companies like Facebook, Google and even his preferred communications outlet, Twitter. The president has claimed, without evidence, that the companies are "against me", and even suggested US regulators should sue them on the grounds of anti-conservative bias.

The firms are already under closer scrutiny than ever by regulators and Congress, following a stream of scandals including Facebook's lapses in opening the personal data of millions of users to Trump's 2016 campaign, and a bipartisan push for new data privacy legislation that has emerged in Congress.

Regulators at the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission are pursuing antitrust investigations against Facebook, Google, Apple and Amazon.

Trump's volley of Twitter messages yesterday had familiar targets - "certain companies", the media and his Democratic rivals - that have resonance with his political base. The president predicted, without foundation, the demise of the media and social media platforms, if he loses to a Democrat in 2020. He hailed himself as "so great looking and smart, a true stable genius".

A "big subject" of the summit would be "the tremendous dishonesty, bias, discrimination and suppression practised by certain companies", Trump said in his tweets.

"We will not let them get away with it much longer," he added.

Accusations commonly levelled by conservatives against social media platforms include anti-religious bias, a tilt against abortion foes and censorship of conservative political views.

Trump has made it a priority to reach out to voters opposing abortion. The anti-abortion groups Live Action and the Susan B Anthony List, say Twitter has blocked their ads. Twitter prohibits paid ads with content "that is inflammatory or provocative and evokes a strong negative reaction".

Donald Trump jr weighed in, tweeting: "Twitter: We won't allow pro-life groups like @LiveAction to run ads on our 'platform'." | AP ANA

urn:contentItem:5SY1-V0W1-JBHT-D38M-00000-00Trump Sides With Conservatives On Shutdown Messaging; Trump Supporters Line Up Early For Tampa Rally; DHS Addresses Cyberattacks; Leslie Jones Speaking Out; Tech Stocks Under Pressure2018-07-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:08ZLexisNexisTrump Sides With Conservatives On Shutdown Messaging; Trump Supporters Line Up Early For Tampa Rally; DHS Addresses Cyberattacks; Leslie Jones Speaking Out; Tech Stocks Under PressureLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Tuesday, July 31st. Your top stories at 8:00 a.m. Eastern. Earnings driving the action on Wall Street, three Dow components reporting today and mixed picture so far but Apple is the number one in focus. That tech giant's results after closing bell today. We have a preview plus a closer look at the tech wreck.

Key stocks entering correction territory, down 10 percent or more from their recent highs. Checking the market action this morning, we have a 30- point gain on Dow futures, green across the board on the Dow, S&P, and NASDAQ 100. This after a different story yesterday, declines across the board with the NASDAQ composite being the hardest hit despite. But recent weakness all of the major market gages.

Including the Dow transports and the Russell 2000 are on track for monthly gains as we wrap up July today. In Europe we've had some mixed markets right now, the DAX of the three major markets there is in negative territory, ever so slightly. And reading on the Eurozone economy showing slowing growth in the second quarter. In Asia overnight, markets heading higher across the board. The only loser there, the Hang Seng in Hong Kong.

The Bank of Japan surprising investors by keeping its monetary policy unchanged. Protecting our border. President Trump doubling down on his calls for a government shutdown if funding is not approved.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: If we don't get border security after many, many years of talk within the United States, I would have no problem doing a shutdown. It's time we had proper border security.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: One new development according to the Wall Street Journal, a change in the timeline? The President reportedly putting a shutdown on hold until after the midterm elections. We will hear from Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen on that, plus cybersecurity later this hour. And President Trump is speaking tonight in Tampa. What will he say then? You have to watch Fox Business to find out.

Not taking the bait. Kim Kardashian appearing on Jimmy Kimmel last night where she was asked about her Oval Office visit. What she said about the Commander-in-Chief coming up. The warning about drinking and shopping. You won't believe how much people are spending online after throwing back a few. Whiskey drinkers are the most frugal. We'll tell you what type of drinkers are the biggest spenders.

We have Kat Timpf here to weigh in on that. And so much more this morning. She's a Fox News Contributor, Wall Street Journal Economics Editor Jon Hilsenrath and CFRA investment strategist Lindsey Bell. Great to see you. Nothing wrong with that though because you know what, online, you can return almost anything.

KAT TIMPF, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Yes, absolutely. Except I never do because it's too complicated. You got to put it back in the package, you got walk downstairs, well, tick the elevator but still you got to wait for elevator rather than stay on couch.

MCDOWELL: We weigh in.

JON HILSENRATH, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: To hear how bourbon drinkers fair in this whole --

TIMPF: I'm a tequila drinker myself, so --

MCDOWELL: Yes. Tequila will get you into trouble. Just saying. So many ways. But first, two more Dow companies out with earnings this morning. All eyes will be on Apple, that company reports after the will be. Nicole Petallides at the New York Stock Exchange with the details. Hey, Nicole.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey, good morning, guys. All right. Note to self. No drinking and shopping. Looking at the earnings overall. So, so far we're beating for estimates overall, tech in particular is worrisome. But let's take a look at these Dow components. So Pfizer, this is to the downside this morning. They beat on profit, they did well with the pneumonia vaccine or arthritis drug.

But the truth to the matter is that they lowered the revenue expectation for 2018, that is down .3 percent. Procter & Gamble also to the downside. Quarterly sales were below the estimates. This is Gillette Razors. This whole grooming unit was a miss, and so that's also lowered, got to get to tech. When we talk about the FAANG index which I watch regularly here on the big board.

I talked to the traders, I talked to people who were managing money, they all seem to say how important is Apple is after the bell. Not only are we to hear about the products, and what's going on in China, we're hearing about strengthening dollar. All of these things have factored in but tech in particular has been selling off without any -- they're just selling it all. And so, if they sell off Apple, does that mean it breaks the trend lines.

Because I talked to technical analysts too, watching the upwards trend line of tech. And now forget it. This will be the last chance to hold on to tech, that's what they're saying. So they've made this very, very severe for today's afternoon numbers. Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Nicole. Lindsey Bell, really quickly on this. To point this out, we talk about this 10 percent correction in this FAANG index, this is the second time it happened this year. And also it last happened three years ago. So again, you want to talk about stocks that have been able to recover from these past he sell-offs in recent years worth noting.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Exactly. And you've seen -- like I said earlier, some of the stocks in this index have done really well, Alphabet which is Google, Amazon, other stocks like Microsoft, AMD like the -- there are names that are doing really well that I think can lift this up. It seems to be a social media issue more than an overall tech issue. And we saw what Amazon reported result, that stock went up, lifted the group up.

We'll see if Apple can do same.

MCDOWELL: Great. Switching gears. President Trump heading to Florida later today where he is expected to tout strong economic growth at a workforce event and a Make America Great Again rally. Blake Burman joins us live from the White House with more details. Blake?

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Hi there, Dagen. Good morning to you. President Trump reiterating yesterday here at the White House that he is willing to meet with just about anybody. We've already seen the President meet with leaders of North Korea, the President of Russia as well. And President Trump saying yesterday that he is also willing to meet with Iran's President Hassan Rouhani.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I don't do that from strength or from weakness. I think it's an appropriate thing to do. If we could work something out that's meaningful, not the waste of paper that the other deal was, I would certainly be willing to meet.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Do you have preconditions for that meeting?

TRUMP: No preconditions, no. They want to meet, I'll meet anytime they want. Anytime they want.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: However, the Secretary of State Mike Pompeo did appear to lay out some conditions in an interview yesterday saying that Iran needs to make it known that it's worthwhile to enter into a nuclear agreement, change their behavior in the Middle East and change how they treat their own people. A spokesperson for the National Security Council backed that up in a statement saying that the U.S. would be willing to reestablish diplomatic relations with Iran.

And could pull back sanctions but also warned the following, "this relief is only possible if there are tangible demonstrated and sustained shifts in Tehran's policies until then the sting of sanctions will only grow more painful if the regime does not change course. The head of Iran Strategic Council responding this morning by the way saying that Iran does not see any value in the President's offer to sit down for negotiations.

Meantime, as well in the world stage today, Dagen, a U.S. official knowledge of the intelligence assessment tells Fox this morning that the latest assessment does show that North Korea is continuing to build its missile capabilities up and that includes ICBM, the intercontinental ballistic missiles. Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Blake. Blake Burman at the White House for us. Here now with reaction, Byron York, Washington Examiner Chief Political Correspondent, Fox News Contributor. Byron, we're less than 100 days away from the midterm elections. What are you listening for in tonight's rally because there is so much on the President's plate each and every day. And when -- it seems like that his plate is full, he add something else.

BYRON YORK, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Well, if you talk Republican strategists who were trying to help the Republican Party keep control of the House, you know, they'll tell you they want him to talk about the economy, they want him to talk a lot about the economy, they want to talk about how Democrats want to get rid of ICE. They want him to talk about immigration, they want him to talk about the specter of Nancy Pelosi being Speaker of the House.

They want him to talk about all of that stuff.

MCDOWELL: Will he? Because again --

YORK: Well, among other things, yes. I think -- I think he probably will but go all over the place, but the -- a number of these strategists have been kind of rattled by the last month. They were pretty confident a month ago if you talked to them but the whole border family separation thing followed by the President's performance in Helsinki, really spooked some of them.

They've seen some of the President's numbers and key Congressional districts go down with those independent voters they're trying to get. So they are worried about the amount of noise that comes out of the White House at any given time but they really wish they could keep pushing economy, ICE, Supreme Court, Nancy Pelosi, that kind of stuff.

MCDOWELL: The President tweeted moments ago speaking of adding something else to the list of topics this morning. Collusion is not a crime. That doesn't matter because there was no collusion except by crooked Hillary and the Democrats. Your reaction to that? I'm sure that the "strategists" don't want him tweeting about that but good luck telling the President what to do.

YORK: Well, actually, the President has been pretty effective when -- with this. If you go back to the hiring of Rudy Giuliani and the beginning of Rudy Giuliani kind of being the face of the President's defense and Emmet Flood being the inside player on the President's defense. By the way, when is the last time anybody's heard Emmet Flood come out and say anything? Does not happen. They clearly got kind of a two-track effort going on.

And I think if you look at the polls showing the number of people who have confidence in Robert Mueller and his investigation that has been slowly ticking downwards since the President did this. My guess is the President is doing this because he thinks it works.

MCDOWELL: Right. Because you changed -- you get all the Democrats if you listen to any of these other networks, they literally talk about Russia non-stop. They don't talk about anything that truly matters to anybody who is working hard and trying to support their family in this country. All they talk about is Russia and who is getting interviewed by Mueller who is subpoenaed.

And it's forcing the Democrats, they almost -- the Trump supporters want the Democrats to talk about impeachment because he's a loser.

YORK: They absolutely do. And I mean go back to 2006, if you remember, George, the Iraq War was in terrible shape, George W. Bush very unpopular. A number of Democrats were saying if we win the control of the House in 2006, there is going to be impeachment. And it really did not fly and Nancy Pelosi who wanted to be speaker, she turned out she did, basically came out and said impeachment is off the table.

Now, there are a lot more Democrats who say that if the party wins, they want Donald Trump impeached, but it's not working out that well in polls of the general electorate. So I think you're going to see a conflict inside the Democratic Party in August, September, and October about how much to emphasis the whole Trump-Russia thing.

MCDOWELL: Byron, you recently wrote an op-ed in the Washington Examiner on the escalating fear that's approaching as the midterms this fall becoming increasingly imminent. You write this. Perhaps the biggest underlying question of the coming elections is the relationship between presidential job approval and the House GOP's reelection chances. It's often observed that Trump is keeping the favor of his base supporters.

He is but Republican -- something you just mentioned Republican strategists are watching his approval sink. In some educated affluent Congressional districts with lots of independent voters, the party needs to hold the House. I mean, how do you reconcile these two because we were talking to Congressman Ron DeSantis who's running for the governor of Florida earlier.

And President Trump's endorsement of this man, completely shifted the momentum away from his Republican opponent and he has a double-digit lead in the polls in Florida right now for the upcoming primary.

YORK: Absolutely turned it around for Ron DeSantis. That is of course a statewide race and all of the Congressional races are in the Congressional districts. But the big question of the midterms and nobody knows the answer, the big question is what effect will the President's job approval rating have on the voting? In the past, we have generally seen the President below 50 percent job approval rating.

It's harder for his party to keep the House. They tend to lose more seats but people wonder is Trump something different. You have to remember, his Donald Trump's personal disapproval rating was near year 60 percent on Election Day, 2016 when he was elected. And the number of smart Republicans are saying, you know, I just don't know exactly how that works.

MCDOWELL: When you say strategists, I have to chuckle, because, again, President Trump won that election by being himself and doing what he wanted to and he ignored I would say most strategists.

YORK: Oh, absolutely. The only thing here is Donald Trump is not on the ballot, you might think that by listening to this campaign but he is not on the ballot, so it's really unclear how the Trump effect will play out in these midterms.

MCDOWELL: Byron York, always love seeing you, sir.

YORK: Thank you, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Come back soon. Coming up. Talk about a financial hangover. The shocking new study that finds Americans spend more than $30 billion in online shopping when they're drinking.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: The president continues to tweet this morning. He has written this. I am looking into 3D plastic guns being sold to the public already spoke to the NRA doesn't seem to make much sense. This comes after several states are lining up to sue to stop these 3D plastic guns.

Switching gears. The housing market latest challenge finding young workers to build homes. Cheryl Casone has details on this story. Hey, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: It's interesting, Dagen. Good morning. Young people apparently don't want to work in construction, Wall Street Journal reports the percentage of workers who are 24 years old or younger has fallen in nearly the entire country since the last housing boom. That was back in 2005. There is no single reason for the shortage.

But when economists in the industry says the problem is contributing to a labor shortage, that results and fewer homes being built and rising prices for buyers. Shares of two home builders (INAUDIBLE) toll brothers are both down sharply this year. I mean, sharply look at that chart.

OK. Well, in case you missed it. Kim Kardashian-West defended President Trump on Jimmy Kimmel Live last night. No matter how hard Kimmel tried to get her to criticize the president. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KIM KARDASHIAN-WEST, AMERICAN TELEVISION PERSONALITY: I walk in and I'm like I look around and I'm kind of star struck from the Oval Office and the first thing I say in our meeting, I say holy [bleep] we're in the [bleep] Oval Office. That's what I said. That was the first thing I said and I had to take a moment and be like, wait, we're really here. I'm very grateful and I'm very hopeful that more good things are going to come out of our conversation.

JIMMY KIMMEL, AMERICAN TELEVISION HOST: Oh, do you have a list now of people that you might ask him to release from prison?

KARDASHIAN-WEST: I do. I've been working on it.

KIMMEL: Is Melania on it? I know that you're not necessarily a Trump supporter, I know your husband Kenya seems to like him.

KARDASHIAN-WEST: I always respect what other person thinks. I have nothing bad to say about the president.

KIMMEL: Right. Because you still have people on the --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: She held her ground the whole interview, guys. She met with President back in may to discuss the release of Alice Johnson who is serving a life sentence for a nonviolent drug charge in Tennessee. Johnson sentence was commuted by the President in June and she was immediately released from prison.

And then there is this. A new study says that drunk Americans really enjoy online shopping after knocking back a few. Spending a total of $30 billion online each year. More importantly what they drink impacts how much they spend. While shopping on Amazon for instance, gin drinkers tend to spend the most an average of more than $82.00. Rum and vodka drinkers in second and third place both spending 50 bucks.

Followed by those who drink white wine, red wine, tequila, beer and then the last place, I don't know what this means. Folks, but whiskey drinkers spend an average $39.00. Are whiskey drinkers cheap? I don't know. Also note, there is a surge of drunk shopping on Saturday morning around 2 a.m. Shoes and lingerie, some of the more popular items that are bought of 1,000 people surveyed who reported purchasing an item off of Amazon.

While drinking, about 50 percent said yes, they later returned their purchases.

MCDOWELL: Thank you.

CASONE: I will send it over to you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Cheryl. Your reaction, Kat Timpf.

TIMPF: I mean, I'm a tequila drinker but I've definitely spent more than 40 bucks.

MCDOWELL: Yes. You tequila drinkers are like out getting in fights with people (INAUDIBLE)

TIMPF: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Just joking.

TIMPF: You know, me and my bar fighting problem.

MCDOWELL: No. No, no, no. I was just kidding.

TIMPF: Never been in a fight.

MCDOWELL: But by the way, whiskey drinkers having grown up down south bourbon drinkers having fun with friends, shooting pool, like socializing, they're not home shopping.

TIMPF: Right. Well, you know, --

MCDOWELL: Like -- unlike people in New York City who were drinking gin and tonics alone on a Saturday night.

TIMPF: We can't all be popular.

MCDOWELL: But you are popular, Kat. Around here you are. Coming up. We're taking America from hackers. The Department of Homeland Security has created a new cyberhub. We'll speak with the Homeland Security secretary about that ahead. Plus, crude awakening. Why one expert is predicting oil prices could surge to $400 per barrel. We didn't make that up, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: B.P. reporting a surprising second quarter profit tripling it $1.8 billion net gain. This comes after the company announced a multitude billion-dollar deal in the U.S. Shale country here to discuss, PKVerleger president and battle -- excuse, Brattle Group senior adviser, Philip Verleger. Philip, your thoughts on the state of the energy sector right now and your protection for catastrophe?

PHILIP VERLEGER, SENIOR ADVISER, BRATTLE GROUP: Catastrophe, yes. Yes, $400 is a -- is an extreme peak. Look, I'm an economist. B.P. has been doing a really great job in reshaping itself since the Macondo accident. And it's -- this is not surprising. I mean, it's why I don't follow company earnings. The B.P. people have been working extraordinarily hard to bring down costs and trying to bring the more production.

And it's -- B.P. is now leading among the super majors I think.

MCDOWELL: So --

VERLEGER: But --

MCDOWELL: Go ahead, Philip. Finish your thought.

VERLEGER: Well, no, what I was going to say is -- I mean, it's -- and they will do better for the next year, a year and half as crude prices rise. You know, I don't see -- $400 is an extreme point and I used to it to make a -- try to call people's attention to this obscure regulation that could really upset the whole economy in 2000 -- you know, lead to a situation where consumers were paying $6.00, $7.00 a gallon election day 2020. Something nobody wants to see.

MCDOWELL: Jon Hilsenrath, just to explain that. The International Maritime Organization ruled that Phillip is talking about requires shippers to use only low sulfur fuel which will shift five percent of global oil demand away from high sulfur and toward low sulfur. That's going to bring oil prices to 2008 peaks by 2020. Jon?

HILSENRATH: Well, I mean, Philip, I'd like to hear your explanation, you put the $400 a barrel oil price out there. How do you get to that and how does this one obscure regulation get you to that kind of extreme prediction?

VERLEGER: What it does is, you know, I laid out in 2005 why we're going to see a $100 oil. And the -- and same reason. It -- what it does is it put an extreme demand for low sulfur diesel fuel onto the refining system and they can't produce it. So what we're going to see is roughly a million to a million and a half barrel a day, global decline in the use of diesel fuel across the industrial sector. That's what's needed to make the fuel for the maritime organization.

For the -- for the shippers.

BELL: But Philip --

VERLEGER: It's --

BELL: Lindsey Bell, I just -- is there -- you're talking about the refiners having to change, you know, the way they refine the oil. What about --there's another alternative of shifts putting equipment onto their -- to the boat to really address the emission issue. Is that a more efficient way, is that a possible way of addressing this issue?

VERLEGER: Yes, Lindsey. That's absolutely a way. You can't -- what you have to do is put the ship and dry if off and you put the scrubber material in there. So you scrub the fuel the way you scrub on a power plant. Six percent, maybe seven percent of the world shipping capacity will have scrubber by 2020. There are 60,000 to 80,000 ships they think maybe, 6,000, 6500 ships will have scrubbers.

But that leaves a huge number of ships not and many of the large shipping companies are saying that they're going to rely on the oil industry to provide the low sulfur oil. Maersk has made that statement I believe and as the big Costco shipping company from China. So most of the, you know, most of the shipping companies keep saying, look, it is a refiner's obligation to do this. The refiners aren't prepared to make it yet.

MCDOWELL: Philip, it's good to see you. Please come back, sir, often.

VERLEGER: Yes. Thanks.

MCDOWELL: Philip Verleger. More Trump tweets. President Trump tweeting again this. We'll be in Tampa tonight. A big year for Congressman DeSantis who will be a great governor for Florida. Strong on crime, borders and our second amendment. Big help on tax and regulation cuts. Lovers our military and our vets. Has my full and total endorsement. Ron DeSantis who we talked to last hour still has to go up against a challenger.

The Secretary of Agriculture in the State of Florida. That run -- that primary in the Republican Party for the Republican nomination to run for governor is in August. However, President Trump's supporter Ron DeSantis has really turned around things for DeSantis. He as a double-digital lead in the polls now. Coming up. Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen will join us. She will weigh in on the department's security strategy, immigration and much more.

Plus, a new warning for Morgan Stanley. Why the firm is predicting the biggest correction since February pointing to earnings misses from Facebook and Netflix which are now in bear market territory, down more than 20 percent each from their recent highs. We'll be right back.

DANI KLUPENGER, TENNIS CHANNEL HOST: Welcome back to another Tennis Channel Court Report. A special presentation for Fox Business. I'm Dani Klupenger. Former number one Andy Murray made his return to the ATP World Tour at the Citi Open Monday. But the three-time major champion was far from his bet.

Mackenzie McDonald took full advantage of a slow start from the Scott. He's making his comeback after hip surgery. The American closing out the opener 6-3. But a slight struggling with his mobility. Murray managed to claw his lead back into the match, leveling it up after taking the second 6-4.

Sheer determination got Murray across the finish line as he wraps up the hard-fought win 7-5 deep in the decider. But it doesn't get easier, up next, countryman and top 20 star, Kyle Edmund. And don't forget, Tennis Channel's exclusive coverage of the city open from Washington D.C. continues Tuesday at 2:30 p.m. Eastern. I'm Dani Klupenger.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Welcome back. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Tuesday, July 31st, your top stories at 8:30 a.m. Eastern. Three Dow components among the big names reporting earnings today; Pfizer and Procter & Gamble already out with their numbers, some mixed reports there. But this -- and you can see, Pfizer's stock down more than one percent. Procter & Gamble stock, this is premarket trading, down more than three percent. Again, it was a revenue miss for Procter & Gamble.

We've got Apple reporting this afternoon, however, will Apple be able to turn around the likes of Facebook and Twitter? Talk about Facebook and Netflix, those stocks as of yesterday in bear market territory, they are down more than 20 percent from their recent highs. We'll see if Apple can buck that trend.

Futures are showing this right now, we've had gains across the board all morning, reversing losses yesterday, 24-point gain on the Dow Futures. Numbers on personal income and spending, come -- just hitting the wires, both personal income and spending rising four-tenths of one percent, in line with the economists' expectations. The core PCE Index which is the Fed's chosen indicator for inflation, rising 1.9 percent compared to a year ago. So, based on that inflation, looks pretty tame.

In Europe, we look at England, France, and Germany, we have gains in -- on the FTSE 100 in England and the CAC Quarante in France, the DAX heading lower, losing one-quarter of one percent. The Asian markets mostly higher, the Hang Seng the only loser there, down half of one percent.

Are the bears knocking at the door? Analysts at Morgan Stanley say stocks could be in for the biggest correction since February. We have details coming up on that. Plus, building the wall, President Trump speaking out again yesterday on securing America's borders.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Unlike President Obama, I just want great border security. Our countries have learned through hard experience that border security is national security, they are one and the same.

MCDOWELL: The President threatening a government shutdown over border security funding but one administration official tells the Wall Street Journal that the fight will happen after the midterm elections. Roseanne got the boot, Director James Gunn gets fired, one comedian says that we should just take it easy and stop being so sensitive to everything. You cannot wait to hear from her.

And now, to the top story this half hour, protecting America, the Department of Homeland Security hosting a cybersecurity summit today. That's where we find Deirdre Bolton, she is live in New York City with the Secretary of Homeland Security Kirstjen Nielsen. Good morning, Deirdre.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Good morning, Dagen. I certainly am. And I pleased to welcome, of course, Secretary Nielsen. Thank you so much for the time today.

KIRSTJEN NIELSEN, UNITED STATES SECRETARY OF HOMELAND SECURITY: My pleasure.

BOLTON: So, you have this huge cybersecurity summit. You are hosting it today, you have the head of the FBI, you have the head of the NSA, you have Vice President Mike Pence, and then you also have tons of business leaders, CEOs from tech, and banking, and energy. What is the biggest threat right now to our infrastructure?

NIELSEN: The biggest threat in my mind is if we don't partner. So, what we see the adversary is doing is they're crowdsourcing. So, they're using bots, they're using paid influencers, they're using their governments, they're using anyone and everyone that can attack us. So, the biggest threat is if we don't work together to counter that.

BOLTON: So, give me, if you don't mind, Secretary, in order of aggressivity, Russia, China, Iran, North Korea, unknown. So, that's one through five, who's attacking us the most?

NIELSEN: OK. So, it's a good question. They all have slightly different note. So, I would say Russia is very active, they'll continue to be active, we've seen meddling in the election, we've seen meddling with our industrial control systems, we've seen meddling with routers. China has more of a long view, so they're looking more to understand our systems particularly in government, understand who's who, get different access to systems. Iran we see very active and North Korea both but general in their regions. So, they have the capability, we know they have the intent but we don't see them quite as active towards us.

BOLTON: So, what's our response, what's our strategy? You attack us, we hit back 10 times as hard? What can we do to take away an incentive to keep trying to figure out our systems?

NIELSEN: Yes. I mean, I (INAUDIBLE) we do have to move from complacency to consequences and I think you've seen that. So, whether it's through legal means such as indictments, whether it's through sanctions through the Treasury Department, whether it's through diplomatic means such as P&G, we have to have consequences for the activities. We have to call them out and hold them responsible.

BOLTON: So, you're creating a risk management center, and it goes back to this point about coordination, where you really feel the government and private enterprise needs to be coordinated because some business leaders have complained, like, even when I think I'm hacked I don't know who to call.

NIELSEN: Right.

BOLTON: Is this the answer, the risk management center.

NIELSEN: (INAUDIBLE) never call 911. We saw that happened before (INAUDIBLE) communities. No, I think it is. So, how it is now, we have different intel that comes in so we collate at the government level, all the intel unclass and classified. But we needed the private sector perspective to understand the context to which to imply that intel. So, for example, working very closely with the energy sector, the finance sector, and the com sector, if we have a piece of intel, we can see how it fits in to their operational environment and how it could affect them. That helps us prepare, helps them prepare, and helps us be ready for the systemic threats.

BOLTON: So, you mentioned energy, I've heard some people say, parts of our system are so old that it's actually hard to hack, but then we've seen evidence of Russia actually having a certain amount of success in breaching some ports which normally shouldn't have been breached. How do you see it?

NIELSEN: They're trying, for sure. I mean, I think they have some capabilities that's seen in Ukraine, they sort of continue to scan and attempt to access our systems in the U.S. There was one limited distribution asset that they did attack. It would not have had effect on the larger grid, but your point is valid. So, working very closely with the Department of Energy and Secretary Perry will be joining us today to help give the perspective from the energy sector.

BOLTON: Of all the systems that we have, whether it's banking or whether it's internet security, or whether it's the energy grid, what are you most worried about? What keeps you up at night in this cyber context?

NIELSEN: I'm just worried about being behind, right? So, they continue to innovate daily, sometimes by the minute in terms of their different ways that they're attacking us. So, we have to keep up. They're crowdsourcing their attacks that I mentioned earlier so we have to have that partnership. But really, it's evolving threats. So, I worry that at given times, we might not have the authority and resources we need to combat them effectively. So, it's moving towards our toes.

BOLTON: When you talk about resources, what is it like for you to recruit because I'm thinking of computer scientists coming out of MIT would (INAUDIBLE) I mean, that's who you need. You need these code breakers, you need these hackers. It's easier for them to go and work in Silicon Valley.

NIELSEN: Yes, it is. It's much more lucrative. We're working on a variety of different initiatives, everything from exchanging partners with the private sector, so we have a loan executive program, but we also actually are doing something that I think is quite innovative which is working with GSA to develop a whole new GSA system to hire federal employees, that's really based on their skill sets in cyber which might not necessarily equate to the traditional educational requirements.

BOLTON: Now, I know as we talked about it, you have CEOs here. How cooperative is private enterprise with the government. There's a lot of people who don't trust the government.

NIELSEN: Yes, it's taken the DHS about 15 years old, it's taken us probably all 15 of those years to build up the trust. When used to say we're from the government, we're here to help, it wasn't really something people wanted to hear, but I think what you'll hear from the CEOs today is they're coming committed to this partnership, committed -- and that's the full -- it's not just for smiles, it's not just when the attack happens but it's on the planning, the risk assessment, the prioritization, really understand that interdependent fabric between all the sectors.

BOLTON: OK. We know, for example, at the border, Microsoft specifically saying we don't want our facial recognition technology used there. What is your opinion on that?

NIELSEN: I will see to Microsoft their thoughts on that, but sometimes the biometric technology is actually fastest way to confirm an identity. So, we use facial recognition in limited ways right now within the air domain, within aviation, and we find that vastly increases the ability of (INAUDIBLE) of passengers. So, if it's something we can do faster to make it more efficient while still keeping it secured, at DHS, we'll always look for opportunities.

BOLTON: Secretary Nielsen, before we let you go, how do you see this idea of a border wall fitting in with immigration policy and how that fits with security and cybersecurity?

NIELSEN: So, all of this together, we're sort of talking about different walls, aren't we? So, on the border, walls work. We've seen that in (INAUDIBLE) we've seen that in San Diego, we've seen that in other countries. When the wall goes out, it does absolutely serve as not just a deterrent but a physical barrier that makes it much more difficult to access. The same can be true of cyber, so what we're looking at is a system of systems of approach, some are firewalls, but much more than that, it's monitoring on the systems, looking at the network traffic, identifying the threat indicator sharing, mitigation measures. So, similar to immigration, you have to have -- you have to have many, many layers of security in order to assure ourselves we're protecting Americans.

BOLTON: Do you think we're going to see a shutdown based on this issue?

NIELSEN: I think the president has been clear as to what he believes is needed for border security, but from my perspective, we'll continue to work with the appropriators and work with Congress so I can make sure that the men and women of DHS have what they need to do their jobs.

BOLTON: All right. Secretary Nielsen, thank you for the time. We appreciate it. Enjoy the summit.

NIELSEN: Thank you. We will. Great.

BOLTON: Dagen, back to you and studio.

MCDOWELL: Deirdre, thank you for that interview and thanks to the Secretary as well. Coming up, a new warning from Morgan Stanley, why the firm is predicting a correction. And after Facebook and Netflix, they're now in the bear market territory, down 20 percent as of yesterday. And Leslie Jones is speaking out about comedians being politically correct. Stuart Varney is here to weigh in, and I can't wait, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LESLIE JONES, COMEDIAN: Stop walking around, so offended. You're not going to be able to survive life if you walk around offended. Laugh! Laugh! Laugh!

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Comedians underfire. That was "Saturday Night Live!" star Leslie Jones. She's amazing, love her. Telling the ladies of "The View" that everyone needs to just get a life, to paraphrase. Joining me now, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney. Hey, Stuart.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Well, look, I'm glad we decided to highlight this because, you know, it's a part of life, isn't it? You watch those late night comedians, they're awful, they don't make me laugh, they are not funny. I've just had a nice three-day weekend and I took a little time to see some of these late night guys, useless! I mean, they're so negative, so hostile, it's all so political, so divisive, I really welcome Leslie Jones' statement there, and she made it on of all places, "The View."

She's saying, look, "You can't go through life if you are offended by everything, you got to laugh." I think her message is, especially those young people who watch the late night guys, you can't go through life like this, you can't start out being opposed to everything and being sensitive to the slightest slight, you can't do that. I think her message is very important, and I hope it's picked up by other comedians who make it -- who bring back comedy, where you're watching their act and you laugh at it, you laugh with them, you laugh at them, you laugh at the jokes, you smile. If we could get back to that, I'd be delighted, not that I will be watching late night television any time soon again, but it would make a nice change to our life, wouldn't it?

MCDOWELL: Well, Stuart, I will turn this back on itself, because part of what she is saying is there are a lot of people who when those late night comedians -- I agree, I haven't heard once anything funny in a long time from them, but Trump supporters who listen to them, when they try to make a joke about the President, or about Republicans, anything that anyone says, that's meant to be a joke is offensive. And so, in part, that's what Leslie Jones is referring to.

VARNEY: I agree. Yes, that's what -- that's what she's also saying, lighten up. Come on, lighten up. The job of a comedian is to make me smile, it's to make me laugh, and that whole profession of comedians has forgotten that message, and I think Leslie Jones is absolute right to bring it back again.

MCDOWELL: Well, and she's also saying that people who go to these comedy shows, who watch all of these -- the myriad Netflix specials by comediennes and that a lot -- it's not just the comedians, it's the people watching them. They literally come to the table with a list of things that will offend them, down to do not make fun of people who love cats. I love cats, I'm offended by you making fun of cat lovers. It's that granular, and that's why people are walking around, as my mother says, with a mad on all of the time.

VARNEY: Right. Didn't have you have Jimmy Kimmel with Kim Kardashian, trying to make her go after Mr. Trump or be snide in some ways towards him. Well, that's just typical, isn't it? Well, what are they thinking of? I mean, is that funny? Is that what you want to do with your late night spot? I can't believe it.

MCDOWELL: I've made fun of Kim Kardashian a lot or criticized that family a lot, however, I will say this, she held her ground with him. She said, I'm not going to say anything negative. And you know what, she deserves a lot of credit for that.

VARNEY: Look, I think she deserves a lot of credit for making an enormous amount of money without being really good at anything other than being famous. And that, to me, is remarkable feat.

MCDOWELL: Here's a -- we'd take that job, too, I think, if we could get it, just being -- making -- being rich for just being yourself. I think that we'll take that if we can do it, but we have to have other skills.

VARNEY: Yes, it wouldn't work with me, I'm afraid. It just wouldn't work. There you go.

MCDOWELL: Yes, nobody understands what I'm saying. I'm out of time anyways, so good luck with that. Stuart, I love you dearly.

VARNEY: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much. Great to see you.

VARNEY: See you later.

MCDOWELL: He will be up in less than 10 minutes, every weekday 9:00 a.m. to noon, Stuart Varney, "VARNEY & COMPANY." Coming up, Morgan Stanley is warning a correction is looming after earnings misses from Facebook and Netflix. We are breaking down the details, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Investors losing their taste for some key technology stocks, Facebook and Netflix both yesterday, closing in bear market territory, down more than 20 percent from their recent record highs, hit earlier this month. This comes as analysts at Morgan Stanley believe a major sell-off is on the way for the broader markets. Joining us now, S&P Global Market Intelligence portfolio manager Erin Gibbs. What do you make of this, is it going to be these tech stocks that lead the broader market lower?

ERIN GIBBS, PORTFOLIO MANAGER, S&P GLOBAL MARKET INTELLIGENCE: I think it's an overstatement to say that just a couple stocks that have been missing, and yes, they have missed at extreme levels are going to draw all of the entire market down. When you look at the broader S&P 500, we're actually trading at really regional valuations. We're looking at 22 percent growth, and when you look at the beat rates for just for a second quarter and guidance, where the stocks are beating at about an 82 percent rate, that's really high, that's like 10 percent higher than normal. So, the broader market actually looks pretty healthy and while technology has a huge impact on it, I don't see it being able to take the entire market down. And the market is only up four percent year-to-date. I don't see that suddenly making, like, us wiping out all of the gains that we've achieved this year.

TIMPF: Well, I think that this report by Morgan Stanley is it's looking at lagging indicators, it's looking at GDP, it's looking at earnings, so those are lagging indicators. If you look at leading indicators like the stock market and manufacturing data, that's all been really strong. Where do you when you think about investing for the second half of the year, where are you putting your money?

GIBBS: So for us, we've been talking about the difference between the value and growth stocks for a few weeks now, and when you look at the return of growth stocks, they're up about 10 percent year-to-date and values only up about two percent. So, value has been the big laggard and that's definitely -- if you want safety, that's the place that's not going down because you just haven't seen this huge uptick, and that could be an area perhaps later in the year. I'd say it's a little earlier now, August tends to be a bad month anyway, it tends to be a rough month, but I would say in the fall, if -- particularly if we see any preference towards financials, we really start seeing interest rates, the yield curve go higher, that could be an area.

MCDOWELL: Speaking of interest rates, the Federal Reserve meets this week, not expected to raise interest rates but, again, what will investors be looking at?

HILSENRATH: Well, I mean, they're going to be looking at how the Fed describes how the economy is doing, that really is what changes in their statement that comes out tomorrow. I mean, the Fed has going to have to be positive on the economy. You know, four percent growth in the second quarter, inflation that's reaching its target. You know, I think they're going to be projecting at least one more interest rate increase and probably too before the end of the year.

MCDOWELL: And then we got a big old jobs report out on Friday. So, 190,000 jobs expected right now. Erin Gibbs, thank you so much, great to see you. Next time, more time, promise. We'll be right back, everybody.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Kat Timpf, Jon Hilsenrath, Lindsey Bell, come back one and all, thank you so much. "VARNEY & COMPANY" starts now. Stuart, take it away.

VARNEY: Yes, it does. And good morning to you, Dagen. And good morning, everyone. Apple reports today, it's the last of the big tech highflyers to lay out the financial results.

END

urn:contentItem:5SXN-MC81-DXH2-628R-00000-00Trump Sides With Conservatives On Shutdown Messaging; Trump Supporters Line Up Early For Tampa Rally; DHS Addresses Cyberattacks; Leslie Jones Speaking Out; Tech Stocks Under Pressure2018-07-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:08ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTLindsey Bell, Philip Verleger, Erin Gibbs, Kirstjen NielsenNEWSDomestic073103cb.231Trump Sides With Conservatives On Shutdown Messaging; Trump Supporters Line Up Early For Tampa Rally; DHS Addresses Cyberattacks; Leslie Jones Speaking Out; Tech Stocks Under PressureDagen McDowell, Kat Timpf, Nicole Petallides, Jon Hilsenrath, Blake Burman, Byron York, Cheryl Casone, Dani Klupenger, Stuart Varney, Deirdre Bolton

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Tuesday, July 31st. Your top stories at 8:00 a.m. Eastern. Earnings driving the action on Wall Street, three Dow components reporting today and mixed picture so far but Apple is the number one in focus. That tech giant's results after closing bell today. We have a preview plus a closer look at the tech wreck.

Key stocks entering correction territory, down 10 percent or more from their recent highs. Checking the market action this morning, we have a 30- point gain on Dow futures, green across the board on the Dow, S&P, and NASDAQ 100. This after a different story yesterday, declines across the board with the NASDAQ composite being the hardest hit despite. But recent weakness all of the major market gages.

Including the Dow transports and the Russell 2000 are on track for monthly gains as we wrap up July today. In Europe we've had some mixed markets right now, the DAX of the three major markets there is in negative territory, ever so slightly. And reading on the Eurozone economy showing slowing growth in the second quarter. In Asia overnight, markets heading higher across the board. The only loser there, the Hang Seng in Hong Kong.

The Bank of Japan surprising investors by keeping its monetary policy unchanged. Protecting our border. President Trump doubling down on his calls for a government shutdown if funding is not approved.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: If we don't get border security after many, many years of talk within the United States, I would have no problem doing a shutdown. It's time we had proper border security.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: One new development according to the Wall Street Journal, a change in the timeline? The President reportedly putting a shutdown on hold until after the midterm elections. We will hear from Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen on that, plus cybersecurity later this hour. And President Trump is speaking tonight in Tampa. What will he say then? You have to watch Fox Business to find out.

Not taking the bait. Kim Kardashian appearing on Jimmy Kimmel last night where she was asked about her Oval Office visit. What she said about the Commander-in-Chief coming up. The warning about drinking and shopping. You won't believe how much people are spending online after throwing back a few. Whiskey drinkers are the most frugal. We'll tell you what type of drinkers are the biggest spenders.

We have Kat Timpf here to weigh in on that. And so much more this morning. She's a Fox News Contributor, Wall Street Journal Economics Editor Jon Hilsenrath and CFRA investment strategist Lindsey Bell. Great to see you. Nothing wrong with that though because you know what, online, you can return almost anything.

KAT TIMPF, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Yes, absolutely. Except I never do because it's too complicated. You got to put it back in the package, you got walk downstairs, well, tick the elevator but still you got to wait for elevator rather than stay on couch.

MCDOWELL: We weigh in.

JON HILSENRATH, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: To hear how bourbon drinkers fair in this whole --

TIMPF: I'm a tequila drinker myself, so --

MCDOWELL: Yes. Tequila will get you into trouble. Just saying. So many ways. But first, two more Dow companies out with earnings this morning. All eyes will be on Apple, that company reports after the will be. Nicole Petallides at the New York Stock Exchange with the details. Hey, Nicole.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey, good morning, guys. All right. Note to self. No drinking and shopping. Looking at the earnings overall. So, so far we're beating for estimates overall, tech in particular is worrisome. But let's take a look at these Dow components. So Pfizer, this is to the downside this morning. They beat on profit, they did well with the pneumonia vaccine or arthritis drug.

But the truth to the matter is that they lowered the revenue expectation for 2018, that is down .3 percent. Procter & Gamble also to the downside. Quarterly sales were below the estimates. This is Gillette Razors. This whole grooming unit was a miss, and so that's also lowered, got to get to tech. When we talk about the FAANG index which I watch regularly here on the big board.

I talked to the traders, I talked to people who were managing money, they all seem to say how important is Apple is after the bell. Not only are we to hear about the products, and what's going on in China, we're hearing about strengthening dollar. All of these things have factored in but tech in particular has been selling off without any -- they're just selling it all. And so, if they sell off Apple, does that mean it breaks the trend lines.

Because I talked to technical analysts too, watching the upwards trend line of tech. And now forget it. This will be the last chance to hold on to tech, that's what they're saying. So they've made this very, very severe for today's afternoon numbers. Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Nicole. Lindsey Bell, really quickly on this. To point this out, we talk about this 10 percent correction in this FAANG index, this is the second time it happened this year. And also it last happened three years ago. So again, you want to talk about stocks that have been able to recover from these past he sell-offs in recent years worth noting.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Exactly. And you've seen -- like I said earlier, some of the stocks in this index have done really well, Alphabet which is Google, Amazon, other stocks like Microsoft, AMD like the -- there are names that are doing really well that I think can lift this up. It seems to be a social media issue more than an overall tech issue. And we saw what Amazon reported result, that stock went up, lifted the group up.

We'll see if Apple can do same.

MCDOWELL: Great. Switching gears. President Trump heading to Florida later today where he is expected to tout strong economic growth at a workforce event and a Make America Great Again rally. Blake Burman joins us live from the White House with more details. Blake?

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Hi there, Dagen. Good morning to you. President Trump reiterating yesterday here at the White House that he is willing to meet with just about anybody. We've already seen the President meet with leaders of North Korea, the President of Russia as well. And President Trump saying yesterday that he is also willing to meet with Iran's President Hassan Rouhani.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I don't do that from strength or from weakness. I think it's an appropriate thing to do. If we could work something out that's meaningful, not the waste of paper that the other deal was, I would certainly be willing to meet.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Do you have preconditions for that meeting?

TRUMP: No preconditions, no. They want to meet, I'll meet anytime they want. Anytime they want.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Good morning, Dagen. I certainly am. And I pleased to welcome, of course, Secretary Nielsen. Thank you so much for the time today.

KIRSTJEN NIELSEN, UNITED STATES SECRETARY OF HOMELAND SECURITY: My pleasure.

BOLTON: So, you have this huge cybersecurity summit. You are hosting it today, you have the head of the FBI, you have the head of the NSA, you have Vice President Mike Pence, and then you also have tons of business leaders, CEOs from tech, and banking, and energy. What is the biggest threat right now to our infrastructure?

NIELSEN: The biggest threat in my mind is if we don't partner. So, what we see the adversary is doing is they're crowdsourcing. So, they're using bots, they're using paid influencers, they're using their governments, they're using anyone and everyone that can attack us. So, the biggest threat is if we don't work together to counter that.

BOLTON: So, give me, if you don't mind, Secretary, in order of aggressivity, Russia, China, Iran, North Korea, unknown. So, that's one through five, who's attacking us the most?

NIELSEN: OK. So, it's a good question. They all have slightly different note. So, I would say Russia is very active, they'll continue to be active, we've seen meddling in the election, we've seen meddling with our industrial control systems, we've seen meddling with routers. China has more of a long view, so they're looking more to understand our systems particularly in government, understand who's who, get different access to systems. Iran we see very active and North Korea both but general in their regions. So, they have the capability, we know they have the intent but we don't see them quite as active towards us.

BOLTON: So, what's our response, what's our strategy? You attack us, we hit back 10 times as hard? What can we do to take away an incentive to keep trying to figure out our systems?

NIELSEN: Yes. I mean, I (INAUDIBLE) we do have to move from complacency to consequences and I think you've seen that. So, whether it's through legal means such as indictments, whether it's through sanctions through the Treasury Department, whether it's through diplomatic means such as P&G, we have to have consequences for the activities. We have to call them out and hold them responsible.

BOLTON: So, you're creating a risk management center, and it goes back to this point about coordination, where you really feel the government and private enterprise needs to be coordinated because some business leaders have complained, like, even when I think I'm hacked I don't know who to call.

NIELSEN: Right.

BOLTON: Is this the answer, the risk management center.

NIELSEN: (INAUDIBLE) never call 911. We saw that happened before (INAUDIBLE) communities. No, I think it is. So, how it is now, we have different intel that comes in so we collate at the government level, all the intel unclass and classified. But we needed the private sector perspective to understand the context to which to imply that intel. So, for example, working very closely with the energy sector, the finance sector, and the com sector, if we have a piece of intel, we can see how it fits in to their operational environment and how it could affect them. That helps us prepare, helps them prepare, and helps us be ready for the systemic threats.

BOLTON: So, you mentioned energy, I've heard some people say, parts of our system are so old that it's actually hard to hack, but then we've seen evidence of Russia actually having a certain amount of success in breaching some ports which normally shouldn't have been breached. How do you see it?

NIELSEN: They're trying, for sure. I mean, I think they have some capabilities that's seen in Ukraine, they sort of continue to scan and attempt to access our systems in the U.S. There was one limited distribution asset that they did attack. It would not have had effect on the larger grid, but your point is valid. So, working very closely with the Department of Energy and Secretary Perry will be joining us today to help give the perspective from the energy sector.

BOLTON: Of all the systems that we have, whether it's banking or whether it's internet security, or whether it's the energy grid, what are you most worried about? What keeps you up at night in this cyber context?

NIELSEN: I'm just worried about being behind, right? So, they continue to innovate daily, sometimes by the minute in terms of their different ways that they're attacking us. So, we have to keep up. They're crowdsourcing their attacks that I mentioned earlier so we have to have that partnership. But really, it's evolving threats. So, I worry that at given times, we might not have the authority and resources we need to combat them effectively. So, it's moving towards our toes.

BOLTON: When you talk about resources, what is it like for you to recruit because I'm thinking of computer scientists coming out of MIT would (INAUDIBLE) I mean, that's who you need. You need these code breakers, you need these hackers. It's easier for them to go and work in Silicon Valley.

NIELSEN: Yes, it is. It's much more lucrative. We're working on a variety of different initiatives, everything from exchanging partners with the private sector, so we have a loan executive program, but we also actually are doing something that I think is quite innovative which is working with GSA to develop a whole new GSA system to hire federal employees, that's really based on their skill sets in cyber which might not necessarily equate to the traditional educational requirements.

BOLTON: Now, I know as we talked about it, you have CEOs here. How cooperative is private enterprise with the government. There's a lot of people who don't trust the government.

NIELSEN: Yes, it's taken the DHS about 15 years old, it's taken us probably all 15 of those years to build up the trust. When used to say we're from the government, we're here to help, it wasn't really something people wanted to hear, but I think what you'll hear from the CEOs today is they're coming committed to this partnership, committed -- and that's the full -- it's not just for smiles, it's not just when the attack happens but it's on the planning, the risk assessment, the prioritization, really understand that interdependent fabric between all the sectors.

BOLTON: OK. We know, for example, at the border, Microsoft specifically saying we don't want our facial recognition technology used there. What is your opinion on that?

NIELSEN: I will see to Microsoft their thoughts on that, but sometimes the biometric technology is actually fastest way to confirm an identity. So, we use facial recognition in limited ways right now within the air domain, within aviation, and we find that vastly increases the ability of (INAUDIBLE) of passengers. So, if it's something we can do faster to make it more efficient while still keeping it secured, at DHS, we'll always look for opportunities.

BOLTON: Secretary Nielsen, before we let you go, how do you see this idea of a border wall fitting in with immigration policy and how that fits with security and cybersecurity?

NIELSEN: So, all of this together, we're sort of talking about different walls, aren't we? So, on the border, walls work. We've seen that in (INAUDIBLE) we've seen that in San Diego, we've seen that in other countries. When the wall goes out, it does absolutely serve as not just a deterrent but a physical barrier that makes it much more difficult to access. The same can be true of cyber, so what we're looking at is a system of systems of approach, some are firewalls, but much more than that, it's monitoring on the systems, looking at the network traffic, identifying the threat indicator sharing, mitigation measures. So, similar to immigration, you have to have -- you have to have many, many layers of security in order to assure ourselves we're protecting Americans.

BOLTON: Do you think we're going to see a shutdown based on this issue?

NIELSEN: I think the president has been clear as to what he believes is needed for border security, but from my perspective, we'll continue to work with the appropriators and work with Congress so I can make sure that the men and women of DHS have what they need to do their jobs.

BOLTON: All right. Secretary Nielsen, thank you for the time. We appreciate it. Enjoy the summit.

NIELSEN: Thank you. We will. Great.

Well, what are they thinking of? I mean, is that funny? Is that what you want to do with your late night spot? I can't believe it.

MCDOWELL: I've made fun of Kim Kardashian a lot or criticized that family a lot, however, I will say this, she held her ground with him. She said, I'm not going to say anything negative. And you know what, she deserves a lot of credit for that.

VARNEY: Look, I think she deserves a lot of credit for making an enormous amount of money without being really good at anything other than being famous. And that, to me, is remarkable feat.

MCDOWELL: Here's a -- we'd take that job, too, I think, if we could get it, just being -- making -- being rich for just being yourself. I think that we'll take that if we can do it, but we have to have other skills.

VARNEY: Yes, it wouldn't work with me, I'm afraid. It just wouldn't work. There you go.

MCDOWELL: Yes, nobody understands what I'm saying. I'm out of time anyways, so good luck with that. Stuart, I love you dearly.

VARNEY: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much. Great to see you.

VARNEY: See you later.

MCDOWELL: He will be up in less than 10 minutes, every weekday 9:00 a.m. to noon, Stuart Varney, "VARNEY & COMPANY." Coming up, Morgan Stanley is warning a correction is looming after earnings misses from Facebook and Netflix. We are breaking down the details, next.

MCDOWELL: Investors losing their taste for some key technology stocks, Facebook and Netflix both yesterday, closing in bear market territory, down more than 20 percent from their recent record highs, hit earlier this month. This comes as analysts at Morgan Stanley believe a major sell-off is on the way for the broader markets. Joining us now, S&P Global Market Intelligence portfolio manager Erin Gibbs. What do you make of this, is it going to be these tech stocks that lead the broader market lower?

ERIN GIBBS, PORTFOLIO MANAGER, S&P GLOBAL MARKET INTELLIGENCE: I think it's an overstatement to say that just a couple stocks that have been missing, and yes, they have missed at extreme levels are going to draw all of the entire market down. When you look at the broader S&P 500, we're actually trading at really regional valuations. We're looking at 22 percent growth, and when you look at the beat rates for just for a second quarter and guidance, where the stocks are beating at about an 82 percent rate, that's really high, that's like 10 percent higher than normal. So, the broader market actually looks pretty healthy and while technology has a huge impact on it, I don't see it being able to take the entire market down. And the market is only up four percent year-to-date. I don't see that suddenly making, like, us wiping out all of the gains that we've achieved this year.

TIMPF: Well, I think that this report by Morgan Stanley is it's looking at lagging indicators, it's looking at GDP, it's looking at earnings, so those are lagging indicators. If you look at leading indicators like the stock market and manufacturing data, that's all been really strong. Where do you when you think about investing for the second half of the year, where are you putting your money?

GIBBS: So for us, we've been talking about the difference between the value and growth stocks for a few weeks now, and when you look at the return of growth stocks, they're up about 10 percent year-to-date and values only up about two percent. So, value has been the big laggard and that's definitely -- if you want safety, that's the place that's not going down because you just haven't seen this huge uptick, and that could be an area perhaps later in the year. I'd say it's a little earlier now, August tends to be a bad month anyway, it tends to be a rough month, but I would say in the fall, if -- particularly if we see any preference towards financials, we really start seeing interest rates, the yield curve go higher, that could be an area.

MCDOWELL: Speaking of interest rates, the Federal Reserve meets this week, not expected to raise interest rates but, again, what will investors be looking at?

HILSENRATH: Well, I mean, they're going to be looking at how the Fed describes how the economy is doing, that really is what changes in their statement that comes out tomorrow. I mean, the Fed has going to have to be positive on the economy. You know, four percent growth in the second quarter, inflation that's reaching its target. You know, I think they're going to be projecting at least one more interest rate increase and probably too before the end of the year.

MCDOWELL: And then we got a big old jobs report out on Friday. So, 190,000 jobs expected right now. Erin Gibbs, thank you so much, great to see you. Next time, more time, promise. We'll be right back, everybody.

MCDOWELL: Kat Timpf, Jon Hilsenrath, Lindsey Bell, come back one and all, thank you so much. "VARNEY & COMPANY" starts now. Stuart, take it away.

VARNEY: Yes, it does. And good morning to you, Dagen. And good morning, everyone. Apple reports today, it's the last of the big tech highflyers to lay out the financial results.

urn:contentItem:6067-8Y21-JBSJ-9180-00000-00Trump Signals Support For Tech Antitrust Reform In Second Term2020-06-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:08ZLexisNexisWASHINGTON NEWSTrump Signals Support For Tech Antitrust Reform In Second Term

The Daily Caller (6/21, Datoc, 716K) reports that in an exclusive interview Friday, President Trump "signaled his support for modernizing antitrust laws for internet-based companies" in a discussion on potential second term initiatives. The President said it's "unfair what's going on with the conservative voice" and "you'd solve the entire problem of the various, you know, monopolists, if you ever voided" Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act of 1996. He added that an overall antitrust law modernization "could happen," but cautioned that "you've got a lot of forces against, with antitrust."

Barr: Social Media Giants "Starting To Censor" Views With Which They Disagree.

Attorney General Barr, on Fox News' Sunday Morning Futures (6/21, 2.08M), discussed the DOJ's plan to roll back legal protections on technology companies. Barr said, "The basic idea is that if you're acting as essentially a bulletin board...and you're not being selective about it, it's open to all comers, you shouldn't be deemed a publisher. We want to encourage that kind of forum for third-party views. That ran into problems because we wanted to encourage, during the early days of the internet, platforms to take off obscene material or harassing material or other kinds of offensive material like that. What we said was in the law, Section 230, if you take that down, that doesn't make you a publisher - if you take down objectionable material like that. Unfortunately, they started taking down viewpoints and started really being selective and based on whether they agreed with the viewpoint or not taking it down. And that should make them a publisher." Bloomberg (6/21, Yang, 4.73M) reports Barr also "said social media giants are 'starting to censor' views and antitrust law can be used to address their dominance, doubling down on Justice Department proposals to limit legal protections for online platforms such as Facebook and Twitter."

NYTimes' Smith Examines Trump/Facebook Relationship.

Ben Smith of the New York Times (6/21, 18.61M) explores the relationship between President Trump and Facebook, reporting that the President, First Lady, Ivanka Trump, and Jared Kushner dined last fall with Facebook board member Peter Thiel and his husband at the White House. Smith says the "unusual gathering" was "something in between a high-stakes state dinner between the leaders of uneasily allied superpowers and the awkward rehearsal dinner before a marriage that has both families a little rattled." Smith asks if Trump and Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg "reach[ed] some kind of accommodation," writing that Zuckerberg "needs, and appears to be getting, a pass both on angry tweets from the president and the serious threats of lawsuits and regulation that face other big tech companies," while the President has maintained "access to Facebook's advertising platform and its viral power."

Twitter Suspended Commentator Whose Posts Have Been Shared By Trump.

The Washington Times (6/20, Blake, 492K) reports Twitter "said Friday it permanently suspended Katie Hopkins, a conservative British commentator whose posts on the platform had been shared by President Trump on several occasions." A Twitter spokesperson told the Times, "Keeping Twitter safe is a top priority for us - abuse and hateful conduct have no place on our service and we will continue to take action when our Rules are broken." The spokesperson added, "In this case, the account has been permanently suspended for violations of our Hateful Conduct policy." The Times also says that Twitter "did not specify what tweet or tweets prompted the social media service to permanently ban Ms. Hawkins."
