Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:6014-0YN1-JBCN-408B-00000-00Trump signs social media executive order that calls for removal of liability protections over 'censoring'2020-05-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:08ZLexisNexisDONALD-J-TRUMPTrump signs social media executive order that calls for removal of liability protections over 'censoring'Tara Mastroeni

FOX NEWS - Flanked by Attorney General Bill Barr, President Trump signed an executive order in the Oval Office on Thursday that interprets Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act of 1996 (CDA) as not providing statutory liability protections for tech companies that engage in censorship and political conduct.

The president's order, which also cuts federal funding for social media platforms that censor users' political views, came just two days after Twitter took the unprecedented step of slapping a "misleading" warning label on two of Trump's tweets concerning the fraud risks of nationwide mail-in balloting. The move immediately backfired: Experts disputed that Trump's tweet was actually misleading, in part because mail-in balloting has been linked to ongoing fraud; Twitter's fact-check itself contained false statements; and Twitter failed to apply the standard of review to other users.

At Thursday's signing ceremony, Trump called the fact-check "egregious," and held up a photo of Twitter executive Yoel Roth, who heads up the site's fact-checking and rules-making operation. Fox News reported on Wednesday that Roth has mocked Trump supporters, called Trump's team "ACTUAL NAZIS," slammed "scary trannies" in New York City, and called GOP Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell a "bag of farts." (In a statement, Twitter did not dispute Fox News' reporting, but called it "unfortunate.")

"My executive order calls for new regulations under Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act to make it so that social media companies that engage in censoring any political conduct will not be able to keep their liability shield," the president said.

He added: "My executive order further instructs the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to prohibit social media companies from engaging in any deceptive acts or practices affecting commerce. This commerce resides in Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act. ... Additionally, I'm directing the attorney general to work cooperatively with the states ... to enforce their own laws against such deceptive business practices. The states have broad and powerful authority to regulate in this arena."

Under the CDA, platforms are ordinarily not liable for users' defamatory or otherwise problematic posts, while publishers that actively shape and create content do face liability. (Copyright law, which has a strong constitutional foundation, ordinarily does require sites like Twitter to remove offending content, or face liability.)

The CDA, which was drafted in the Internet's early stages to guard against offensive material while also encouraging an open Internet, states: "No provider or user of an interactive computer service shall be treated as the publisher or speaker of any information provided by another information content provider. ... No provider or user of an interactive computer service shall be held liable on account of ... any action voluntarily taken in good faith to restrict access to or availability of material that the provider or user considers to be obscene, lewd, lascivious, filthy, excessively violent, harassing, or otherwise objectionable, whether or not such material is constitutionally protected."

Although the "good faith" standard is ambiguous, UCLA law professor Eugene Volokh has noted that some case law suggests that "blocking material ostensibly because it's offensive but really because it's from your business rival might well be seen as being not in good faith," while "blocking material that you really do think is offensive to many of your users (much like sexually themed or excessively violent or harassing material is offensive to many of your users) seems to be quite consistent with good faith."

Trump's order instructs the federal government to interpret and apply the CDA, as agencies typically do when laws give them that flexibility. "It is the policy of the United States that the scope of that immunity should be clarified: the immunity should not extend beyond its text and purpose to provide protection for those who purport to provide users a forum for free and open speech, but in reality use their power over a vital means of communication to engage in deceptive or pretextual actions stifling free and open debate by censoring certain viewpoints," the order states.

Volokh, for his part, argued that while there could be an argument that providers act in "bad faith" when they remove content they don't truly find objectionable, it would be a nonstarter to argue that removing "offensive" content necessarily transforms a platform into a publisher.

However, Trump made his position on the matter clear. "The choices that Twitter makes when it chooses to suppress, edit, blacklist, shadowban are editorial decisions, pure and simple," Trump said. "In those moments Twitter ceases to be a neutral public platform and they become an editor with a viewpoint."

Indeed, the executive order reads: "It is the policy of the United States to ensure that, to the maximum extent permissible under the law, this provision is not distorted to provide liability protection for online platforms that — far from acting in 'good faith' to remove objectionable content — instead engage in deceptive or pretextual actions (often contrary to their stated terms of service) to stifle viewpoints with which they disagree."

"Section 230 was not intended to allow a handful of companies to grow into titans controlling vital avenues for our national discourse under the guise of promoting open forums for debate, and then to provide those behemoths blanket immunity when they use their power to censor content and silence viewpoints that they dislike," the order adds.

The White House had discussed a social media executive order for the past several months, and lawmakers -- including GOP Sens. Marco Rubio and Josh Hawley -- have increasingly sought CDA reforms.

On Thursday, Trump pointed out that some Democrats agreed with him. Former Vice President Biden, in a January interview with The New York Times, said that Section 230 "should be revoked, immediately should be revoked" because Facebook "is propagating falsehoods they know to be false, and we should be setting standards not unlike the Europeans are doing relative to privacy."

Also at the signing ceremony, Trump openly said he would "shut down" Twitter if he could legally. He also called out Facebook's new oversight "tribunal" for hiring Pamela Karlan, the anti-Trump professor who testified at his impeachment hearing.

"Finally, I'm directing my administration to develop policies and procedures to ensure taxpayer dollars are not going to any social media company that suppresses free speech," Trump said. They're rich enough."

"What they're doing is tantamount to monopoly, to taking over the airwaves," Trump said. "Can't let it happen. Or else we're not gonna have a democracy."

On Wednesday, however, the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals handed Twitter and other tech giants an early win on the issue, finding that in the absence of state action, there can be no First Amendment violation. The court also did not find a Sherman Antitrust Act violation, even though the plaintiffs alleged that big tech was conspiring to advance a left-wing agenda in restraint of commerce.

The president had teased the executive order Thursday morning, saying: "This will be a Big Day for Social Media and FAIRNESS!"

Fox News is told that, separately, the administration is working on a commission to look at alleged anti-conservative bias among big social media platforms.

Meanwhile, Republicans were waging a broad, all-out war against what they perceive as pervasive Silicon Valley bias. Several Republican lawmakers suggested on Thursday they will soon take action against Reddit, saying the influential Internet message board systematically singled out, censored, and destroyed a once-popular pro-Trump "subreddit," or subforum, known as "r/The_Donald."

And, Vox reported on Wednesday that big tech billionares are fighting back against Republican efforts, in part because of Joe Biden's struggling operation. The outlet said LinkedIn founder Reid Hoffman, Facebook co-founder Dustin Moskovitz, Laurene Powell Jobs, and ex-Google CEO Eric Schmidt were leading the charge -- sometimes upsetting Democratic operatives, who had wanted to run their own operation.

Hoffman has been a big financial backer of MotiveAI, which has been linked to spreading overtly fake news. For example, The Daily Beast reported that four Colorado-based companies "associated with MotiveAI" used "50 seemingly independent Facebook pages to purchase ads in 2018" -- including a page that suggested Brett Kavanaugh "had helped Bill and Hillary Clinton cover up the murder of a White House aide."

Hoffman alone has also dumped approximately $10 million into Acronym, which backed the company Shadow -- which, in turn, was behind the disastrous Iowa caucus app.

According to Vox, Acronym hopes to secure another $25 million "to set up seven of its own media properties in swing states, creating local news sites that portray moderate Democratic candidates in a favorable light, but appear to be objective, homespun outlets."

Get updates on this story at Foxnews.com

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RYY-BND1-JBHT-D03H-00000-00Trump Signs Spending Bill; McMaster Out, Bolton In; Trump Taps Bolton as NSA; China Threatens to Retaliate after President Trump Imposed Tariffs on Chinese Goods; ISIS Claims France Attack; Trump Gets Tough on China; Facebook Under Fire; Stocks at Session Lows2018-03-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:08ZLexisNexisTrump Signs Spending Bill; McMaster Out, Bolton In; Trump Taps Bolton as NSA; China Threatens to Retaliate after President Trump Imposed Tariffs on Chinese Goods; ISIS Claims France Attack; Trump Gets Tough on China; Facebook Under Fire; Stocks at Session LowsLanhamFULL TEXT

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: And breaking right now, everybody, it is official, President Trump signing Congress' newly passed, nearly $1.5 trillion spending bill and he just called it ridiculous, all this as the markets, quite frankly, all over the place today. Right now, we are near session highs for the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 137 points. What a Friday.

Thank you for joining us. I'm Lauren Simonetti. I'm in for Trish Regan and welcome to THE INTELLIGENCE REPORT. Well, President Trump shaking Capitol Hill today threatening to veto the spending bill saying it didn't spend enough on his border wall. Then he said he would sign it but never anything like it ever, ever again.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: As a matter of national security, I've signed this omnibus budget bill. There are a lot of things that's I'm unhappy about in this bill. There are a lot of things that we shouldn't have had in this bill but we were, in a sense, forced if we want to build our military. We were forced to have.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: We're going to have more on that straight ahead.

And stocks, as we've noted, down sharply. Yesterday, down in the pre- market. Guess what? They opened higher today but moments after President Trump threatened to veto the omnibus bill came, the markets retreated, went negative then they bounced back again as we learned that the President would sign the spending bill. It's so crazy.

We also have fears of a trade war. They continue today as China now threatens to retaliate after President Trump imposed about $60 billion on tariffs on Chinese goods. What does this mean for the world's two largest economies? We're on that story as well.

But first, we go to Adam Shapiro who is live at the White House with the latest on the spending bill. Adam the guessing game is now over?

ADAM SHAPIRO, FOX BUSINESS REPORTER: The guessing game is over, and you heard the President say he did this for the sake of national security. You heard Defense Secretary Mattis talking about this and this is the largest military spending in U.S. history to help rebuild the nation's military and secure the national defense. But the President is not pleased because, as he said as he was leaving the diplomatic room at the White House, that he very seriously considered a veto because while the administration got some of what it wanted, this didn't fix DACA and he had a message to Hispanic- Americans saying, "Republicans are working in your interest better than Democrats." He was very upset with this.

And as you have -- in the introduction, the sound bite in which he said he would never sign a bill like this again, one way to avoid that, he said, would be to revoke the filibuster the Senate has. Here is the President in his own words.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: To prevent the omnibus situation from ever happening again, I'm calling on Congress to give me a line-item veto for all government spending bills, and the Senate must end, they must end the filibuster rule and get down to work.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAPIRO: Now, political analysts have said, one, even if they had the filibuster removed from the Senate, they were missing John McCain. So the Republicans would not have had the majority that the President thinks that he might have been able to get.

The other issue, of course, was to DACA. The President wanted a fix that would have allowed the DACA students, roughly 800,000 people, to have 2.5 year extension in exchange for the Democrats fully funding the border wall with Mexico $25 billion. The Democrats wanted a permanent fix for the DACA students and other aliens who have come to the United States illegally and the President wouldn't do that because he wanted full funding for the border wall.

Here is what the President said about that situation in the negotiations of the omnibus.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: DACA recipients have been treated extremely badly by the Democrats. We wanted to include DACA. We wanted to have them in this bill. Eight hundred thousand people. And actually it could even be more.

And we wanted to include DACA in this bill. The Democrats would not do it. They would not do it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAPIRO: So Lauren, the President, although he doesn't say he got some of what the administration wanted in the bill, the biggest thing was rebuilding the U.S. Military. And as you heard at the beginning of the 2:00 hour, the President signed this bill, this $1.3 trillion bill, which he called ridiculous. He signed it for the sake of national security.

Back to you.

SIMONETTI: And the defense stocks certainly appreciating that today. They are up sharply. Adam, thank you very much.

SHAPIRO: Yes.

SIMONETTI: All right. Joining me now is the American Majority CEO, Ned Ryun, to talk about everything we just heard and everything that's gotten down the past 24 hours or so. Right now, we have averted a government shutdown. The question is, is that bad for Republicans because basically we control the White House and Congress as Republicans, and we just -- you had the President sign the second biggest spending bill ever, would a veto, Ned, have been worse? A government shutdown?

NED RYUN, CEO, AMERICAN MAJORITY: I actually think Trump was morally obligated to veto this omnibus bill. Let's not forget, Congress could have passed a short-term funding bill to keep the government open. This omnibus is a big government dream come true, and Trump, you know, two weeks ago, the President should have engaged more heavily.

The second best time was now veto the bill and start negotiating for a better deal on just a wide variety of fronts. I mean take away the names of those people that sign this, Republican Congress and the Republican President. This seems like we just went back to the future where this could be done by Obama and the Democrat Congress signing a $1.3 trillion bill to take our national debt to $22 trillion. It's hard to keep track of what our national debt is.

And the amazing thing to me in all of this, Lauren, is the facts that there was very little that Trump actually got. I know, he wants to promote the national security and the spending on the military, when it really comes down to it, the new funding for new wall is really just for about 33 feet of new wall. This is one of the biggest issues that he was elected on. And out of $1.3 trillion bill, we couldn't find $21billion to $25 billion to build the southern wall.

And the thing is, the social concern that I'm also deeply disappointed about in this omnibus, there's still over half a billion in annual funding for Planned Parenthood. I see very little to be happy about in this. And when it comes down to the military spending, Lauren, if he had vetoed this bill and forced them to actually negotiate and challenge them and dared them to not fund the military, he would have won that bet.

SIMONETTI: All right. Well, Ned, stay here. I also want to bring in the American University Scholar, Capri Cafaro joining us now.

Good to see you, Capri.

CAPRI CAFARO, AMERICAN UNIVERSITY SCHOLAR: Absolutely, anytime.

SIMONETTI: I want to talk to you about something that Senator Bob Corker tweeted. I love the tweet. He said, "Please do, Mr. President," meaning veto this bill. "I'm just down the street and will bring you the pen. The spending levels without any offsets are grotesque, throwing all of our children under the bus. Totally irresponsible."

Are we now having the President just sign a $1.3 trillion spending bill? Are we mortgaging millennials' futures? Are we killing our kids and grandkids?

CAFARO: Well, I mean, any time that you actually, you know, spend without offset, certainly, I mean, we're continuing to increase the deficit and debt. And I do think it's interesting, you know, Bob Corker and Rand Paul and many other, you know, stalwart Conservatives there, deficit hawks, certainly, are not excited about a $1.3 trillion spending bill, regardless what's in it. And so, I think, that this is a fundamental discussion amongst the nuances and the branches of the Republican Party.

Donald Trump has never been an ideological purist, and whether it is, you know, his issues with trade and tariffs or, you know, these kind of things.

SIMONETTI: Yes.

CAFARO: I mean, he basically said, "I might veto this bill because, number one, it doesn't have more spending and, number two, per the DACA recipients. So, you know, if you are a Freedom Caucus guy, you scratch your head.

SIMONETTI: He's all about the negotiation, Ned. He's all about the art of the deal and the compromise. So he basically said as I saw it, Ned, "I'll give you what you want on DACA. You give me what I want on my wall." But neither seemed happen?

RYUN: No, neither seemed happen. This is why I'm a little perplexed as to how this all went down when neither party walked away with what they wanted.

Lauren, Trump ran on, I am going to come to Washington. It will not be business as usual. I will drain the swamp. We will shake up D.C.

What we saw today is business as usual. The swamp on the rise. We did not see anything that he ran on in 2016. And people like me were voting for an outside the box candidate, and what you saw today with him signing this bill.

And, again, Democrats didn't get DACA. He didn't get his wall. We got $1.3 trillion. The taxpayers got saddled with $1.3 trillion extra in spending. I'm perplexed as to what we actually voted for in 2016, because right now what we're seeing is nothing what we expected on that campaign just a year and a half ago.

SIMONETTI: Yes. And, you know, I'll give you the final answer here, Capri. I asked Ned this question earlier, should the President just have let the government shutdown over this?

CAFARO: I don't think so. I think that that would have been irresponsible. You know, they're on recess.

I think it's important that, you know, you move the ball forward, and I think he actually framed this very well actually for the 2018 midterms. He tried to blame Democrats for overspending and he sent a very strong message to Washington, to Congress saying, "We want a certain number of kind of procedural reforms." So I think he's setting the stage saying, "Never again. I'm going let this go, and if you don't do XYZ, there is a going to be wrath.

SIMONETTI: You've been warned. All right. Capri, Ned, thank you to both of you. Have a good weekend.

RYUN: Thanks Laura.

SIMONETTI: All right. Let's turn back to the chaotic markets. Right now, stocks are higher. Paring gains, we did hit session highs on President Trump's decision to sign the $1.3 trillion spending bill in order to fund the military the way they need and to keep the government open. Right now, Dow industrials up 74 points. The week has been terrible.

Let's bring in Vision 4 Fund Distributors Vice President, Heather Zumarraga, along Tematica Research CIO, Chris Versace.

Good to see you, Heather and Chris.

HEATHER ZUMARRAGA, VICE PRESIDENT, VISION 4 FUND DISTRIBUTORS: Hi.

CHRIS VERSACE, CIO, TEMATICA RESEARCH CIO: Thanks for having me.

SIMONETTI: You know, they say it's been a chaotic few days for the markets. Heather, let me ask you first. What do you think investors are responding to most, the fact we are keeping national debt at astronomical levels and only growing it or growing trade war?

ZUMARRAGA: I think a growing trade war. Investors are responding to that more. I know that we're rallying on the backs of the announcement that President Trump is not going to veto the spending bill, Lauren. But I think trade is still a wild card in the markets right now.

We really don't know the details of final legislation, and so how will that impact the industrials, the materials, the metals, even technology. I think that we'll still weigh on investors' minds and there's more downside to come. But the fundamentals are still in place, earnings are up, inflation remains low and unemployment is low. So, that's great.

SIMONETTI: Chris, we had a lot of guests on the show yesterday when the market was down 724 points at the end of the day, and they were kind of saying, yes, this is no big deal, this is all part of the negotiation of the President. We think when you take a scalpel to these tariffs, we're going to exempt the right people and everybody can just breathe a sigh of relief. And in a sense, they were right today, and I point out Boeing shares. Boeing is responsible for most of the Dow's climb. Is that signaling to you that everything might be OK in the end as we're gambling with U.S. versus China versus the rest of the world?

VERSACE: Yes, I think what you're seeing is usual stock market, you know, shoot first, ask questions later.

SIMONETTI: Yes.

VERSACE: You know, when you look at the data that we're getting, we saw the March Flash PMI come out, you know, signaling an improvement in the economy. I think the big issue that people are getting caught up in is, you know, demand is improving but the question is, what's the cost structure going to be? And I think, that's what getting people a little nervous. You know, if we do see these tariffs going into effect, obviously, steel, aluminum will move higher. If the response into effect, other costs could move higher as well.

And remember, we're getting ready for the March-quarter earnings season where the markets predicated on 18 percent to 20 percent EPS bump for the S&P 500 this year. If that story starts to come undone a little bit, it likely means the market will give some ground back. So I think what you're seeing now is the market getting prepared for that potential conversation, but there are still strong well-positioned companies out there. Perhaps we can buy them now at even better prices.

SIMONETTI: So, Heather, should we buy more domestic companies. Fewer multinationals. And I say that because, what, Nike gets 15 percent of its revenue from China, right?

ZUMARRAGA: Yes.

SIMONETTI: Starbucks, about the same percentage from China. And if we have a different relationship with China, maybe our big companies need to rethink their strategy in order to keep their earnings strong?

ZUMARRAGA: Yes, you're right. Over the short term, I think you can look at smaller cap companies based in the U.S., Russell 2000 is a good gauge of small cap companies, that aren't heavily impacted of potential trade wars or China retaliation of our tariffs. And so these global multinational companies would be impacted the most.

I just don't think it makes sense right now to place a bet on a direction long or short on a global multinational when we don't have the final details. Go to Vegas.

SIMONETTI: We don't know.

ZUMARRAGA: Yes, you'd be better off.

SIMONETTI: No, that's an excellent point. And, Chris, maybe you can help explain to me how tariffs on, let's say, solar panels, washing machines and steel deal with the Chinese theft of our trade secrets, our technology, our intellectual property?

ZUMARRAGA: They do.

VERSACE: I would like to be able to say that but I know the answer to that, but those are two are very different things. I mean, you know, when we talk about, you know, the tariffs in a way to help support our national security and prevent issues from happening, I think, a lot of people can get behind that. I think when we talk about washing machines, solar panels and the other things where we're going to see costs driven up, I think people, they get caught in the crosshairs a little bit understanding that we want to buy American but we also have economy that's predicated on cash strapped consumers trying to spend and spend more, which means we need cheaper alternatives. Hence, some of these goods coming in that we've been relying upon from China.

So, it's an interesting Catch-22, but I think the long-term question is if we can get our capacity in the U.S. up to meet demands, get better pricing, then we can get better paying jobs in the U.S. and help continue the rebound in the economy.

SIMONETTI: Heather, you talked about this earlier, and I'm not going to -- I agree with you. Employment situation is looking better, corporate earnings are strong, the economic data has been good. But when you look at numbers, last year GDP in the U.S. averaged 2.3 percent. Guess what it averaged in China? Six point nine percent. They transitioned from a made- in-China economy to a made-for-China economy, and we need to stop that.

ZUMARRAGA: Yes, they're still trying transition to consumption economy in China. And, look, the data that comes out of China in terms of GDP, I never really -- you don't know if you can trust the data that's coming out of China. They always seem to meet or beat their GDP forecast. So, it's always looking rosy over in China.

But, look, they need us as much as we need them. We import about $500 billion of stuff from them every year, and although there is a massive trade deficit, we don't want to hurt China. In the end, we just want more, fair playing field, and that's what we're going after. I'm just not sure tariffs are the best way to do it.

SIMONETTI: And arguably, who needs who more than the other? Heather, Chris, I guess, we don't have all the answers today. Thank you so much.

ZUMARRAGA: You got it.

SIMONETTI: Have a great weekend.

ZUMARRAGA: You, too.

SIMONETTI: Well, President Trump is signing the massive spending bill today saying he'll do it for national security. This, as he names former U.S. Ambassador to the U.N. John Bolton as his next National Security Adviser. Ambassador Bolton is a foreign policy hawk when it comes to issues like Iran and North Korea. So how is all of this going to play out on the world stage? We're going to discuss that with Retired Four-star General Jack Keane, in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

SIMONETTI: Final day of a tough week at the office. We've got less than two hours left and the markets are all in the negative. The Dow is down two points. If we're lower today, we're -- this will be the third day of losses in a row and pretty significant losses at that. S&P is down 11 points and the NASDAQ selling off the most here on percentage terms by almost three-quarters of one percent.

Just moments ago, the President invokes national security in his reason for signing the $1.3 trillion spending bill vowing that our military will be the strongest ever, defense stocks rallying on this.

He also tapped Former Ambassador and Fox News Contributor, John Bolton, as his new and third National Security Adviser. Bolton was known for having hawkish positions on Iran and North Korea. And earlier today, he told Stuart Varney this.

JOHN BOLTON, INCOMING NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISER: I think my view is the same as the President's, which he's described as the worst deal in American diplomatic history. GEN. JACK KEANE (RET.), FOX NEWS SENIOR STRATEGIC ANALYST: Well, I think what's the hardest thing about government and particularly Executive branches everybody starts a job that they've never had before on the same day. And now the President's a year plus into his job, and I think he understands the presidency now, he understands his role. He knows what he's bringing to the table. What strengths and weaknesses. And he kind of knows what he wants from the staff and also from his Cabinet officials, that's why he's making these changes, because --

SIMONETTI: So it seems like --

KEANE: -- he knows what he wants.

SIMONETTI: It seems like chaos in the White House is really just growing pains and now he's got the team in place that he wants.

KEANE: Yes, pretty much.

SIMONETTI: OK.

KEANE: I don't think he's finished yet, but it is pretty -- and I think when you look at, you know, Mike Pompeo over at State and --

SIMONETTI: Yes.

KEANE: -- and Kudlow in as Economic Adviser and John Bolton, all three of these people I know and have great respect for them, they're going fit right like a hand in a glove with what the President is thinking. They won't agree with him on everything and I don't think the President necessarily wants that. But he clearly wants someone who is going to get right behind his agenda and support it.

And, you know, if you spend so much time around these people, you kind of want to like them as well.

SIMONETTI: Yes, let's talk about John Bolton. Because he is known as being a military action type of guy, definitely hawkish when it comes to foreign policy. He'll start officially in April, which is interesting because in May, the President is expected to decide the fate of the Iran nuclear deal and he's also expected to meet with the leader of North Korea. How do you think John Bolton will affect any of those decisions and meetings?

KEANE: Well, first of all, Bolton agrees with the President's national security strategy. We're turning to a big power competition, again, with Russia, China, Iran, rogue state like North Korea who was nuclearizing ICBM's and is threatening the American people. So Bolton's approach to that, as is the President's approach, is to stand up to it not to confront it. All those countries we're talking about.

SIMONETTI: All right.

KEANE: Not to appease these countries as the previous administration has done, which has weakened the relationship that our allies have with each other and also with us and is emboldened our adversaries. So, if you want the diplomatic situation to work effectively, our adversary has to know that we're at least willing to use a military option if it's necessary and that's what the President has been trying to convince Kim Jong-un of for a year plus now.

"Yes, I'm imposing economic sanctions on you, but I'm also wanting to use a military option if those sanctions fail." And I think Bolton will come in and reinforce that very solidly along with the rest of the national security team.

SIMONETTI: He just -- in the end of February, wrote an op-ed in "The Wall Street Journal" basically saying talking doesn't work. The title of this article was "The Legal Case for Striking North Korea First." So we know who's in charge here and what we're playing with.

The other issue, and this is something Mr. Bolton certainly knows, is that North Korea often makes you think they're willing to negotiate when really they're just trying to buy themselves time to further develop or hide their weapons.

KEANE: Well, that certainly has been the pattern for 25 years.

SIMONETTI: Yes.

KEANE: In other words, the goal with the negotiations, they buy some time, they advance their technology and they get concessions. We don't know for sure whether these negotiations are sincere or they're phony like the others. But we're going to find out here pretty quick.

SIMONETTI: And what about Russia? It seems like Mr. Bolton and the President have different -- Trump has been criticized for appeasing or overlooking some of the things that Russia does. And it seems Mr. Bolton would have a more hard line on Russia?

KEANE: I think so. Most of us take a harder line dealing with Russia than the President has on all of these issues. And now, he has stood up to Russia to be sure. He is providing lethal aid to the Ukrainian, something the previous administration never did.

He struck Assad's air power 36 hours after they used chemical weapons, and those chemical weapons had passive approval of the Russians in doing that, you know, who is a client state of Russia. And clearly we're now sanctioning Russia. But I agree, I think what the President is in his head with this thing, I think, it's a mistake to think he is soft on Russia, because I don't buy that.

I think what he believes himself is that -- he's itching to get into the room with Putin. And the reason for that is he knows that Putin has manipulated his three predecessors quite successfully. And I think he believes, "You know, I've dealt with people like this before, I know where he's coming from. I know he's a thug and a bully, but I'm not going to say that in public because I don't want to forfeit my ability to have a real conversation with this guy." I think that's where the President's head really is. And we'll see.

SIMONETTI: Well said, General Keane. Thank you very much.

MALANGA: -- all the lost is strange here. Well, look I think that even most free traders will tell you that there's imbalance because China cheats. China has -- our agreements with them are, in a sense, unfair. They demand technology from our companies --

MALANGA: -- in order for some companies to go over this, we have to move jobs over there.

The President himself who called China a currency manipulator during his campaign, he's not declared China a manipulator. And then he pulled them back on Canada and Mexico, whether they had actually planned that or whether they just said, "oops!" you know, now our trading partners are getting upset with us.

But the real question, I'll give you an example, OK. Trump, one of the ways that you want to increase an imbalance like this is basically to create more opportunities for American companies.

The Trans-Pacific Partnership was going to be an opportunity. It wasn't a well-negotiated trade deal, OK? But there was a chance to make that better and to create opportunities with Asian trading partners in opposition for China. Instead Trump just said, "We're going to abandon it, we're done with it." That, you see --

SIMONETTI: Do you think we get back into it on different terms?

MALANGA: -- yes, definitely on different terms, but thing is you had a framework, you had a negotiation, go forward with that. So, listen, it's not adequate enough, we're still on the losing end with you folks but we all need to be united against China. But that's not what the President did. So, that's where he's sending mixed messages.

SIMONETTI: Do you think we're starting to align as we do, you know, team Washington versus team Beijing here? You see these tariffs with many exemptions. MALANGA: Well, the interesting thing is, you know, on the list of potential currency manipulators are South Korea, Japan, Germany, and European Union. So they're grouped in there with China, OK. There's no -- we have imbalances, OK?

We have with other countries too, where we essentially allow them more access to our markets than they allow us to their markets. Trump is right to focus on that. There's nothing wrong with that. But the point is whether a trade war in which he seems to be picking his targets and then pulling back, he's sending mixed messages to people rather than getting out and then create more -- demanding more opportunity for American companies overseas. That's absolutely a strategy.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: I was just going to say, if you want to one person, Elon Musk, he actually was kind of funny about it. I swear that he got nothing, he was like, oh, yes, I didn't even realize that SpaceX or Tesla had their own pages, 2.5 million --

LOUIS BASENESE, FOUNDER; DISRUPTIVE TECH RESEARCH: Yes, it is. I think Facebook widely recognized long ago that they needed to have their tentacles into our lives across multiple platforms.
