Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RYY-BND1-JBHT-D03X-00000-00Trump Signs Spending Bill; McMaster Out, Bolton In; Trump Taps Bolton as NSA; China Threatens to Retaliate after President Trump Imposed Tariffs on Chinese Goods; ISIS Claims France Attack; Trump Gets Tough on China; Facebook Under Fire; Stocks at Session Lows2018-03-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:08ZLexisNexisTrump Signs Spending Bill; McMaster Out, Bolton In; Trump Taps Bolton as NSA; China Threatens to Retaliate after President Trump Imposed Tariffs on Chinese Goods; ISIS Claims France Attack; Trump Gets Tough on China; Facebook Under Fire; Stocks at Session LowsLanhamFULL TEXT

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: And breaking right now, everybody, it is official, President Trump signing Congress' newly passed, nearly $1.5 trillion spending bill and he just called it ridiculous, all this as the markets, quite frankly, all over the place today. Right now, we are near session highs for the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 137 points. What a Friday.

Thank you for joining us. I'm Lauren Simonetti. I'm in for Trish Regan and welcome to THE INTELLIGENCE REPORT. Well, President Trump shaking Capitol Hill today threatening to veto the spending bill saying it didn't spend enough on his border wall. Then he said he would sign it but never anything like it ever, ever again.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: As a matter of national security, I've signed this omnibus budget bill. There are a lot of things that's I'm unhappy about in this bill. There are a lot of things that we shouldn't have had in this bill but we were, in a sense, forced if we want to build our military. We were forced to have.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: We're going to have more on that straight ahead.

And stocks, as we've noted, down sharply. Yesterday, down in the pre- market. Guess what? They opened higher today but moments after President Trump threatened to veto the omnibus bill came, the markets retreated, went negative then they bounced back again as we learned that the President would sign the spending bill. It's so crazy.

We also have fears of a trade war. They continue today as China now threatens to retaliate after President Trump imposed about $60 billion on tariffs on Chinese goods. What does this mean for the world's two largest economies? We're on that story as well.

But first, we go to Adam Shapiro who is live at the White House with the latest on the spending bill. Adam the guessing game is now over?

ADAM SHAPIRO, FOX BUSINESS REPORTER: The guessing game is over, and you heard the President say he did this for the sake of national security. You heard Defense Secretary Mattis talking about this and this is the largest military spending in U.S. history to help rebuild the nation's military and secure the national defense. But the President is not pleased because, as he said as he was leaving the diplomatic room at the White House, that he very seriously considered a veto because while the administration got some of what it wanted, this didn't fix DACA and he had a message to Hispanic- Americans saying, "Republicans are working in your interest better than Democrats." He was very upset with this.

And as you have -- in the introduction, the sound bite in which he said he would never sign a bill like this again, one way to avoid that, he said, would be to revoke the filibuster the Senate has. Here is the President in his own words.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: To prevent the omnibus situation from ever happening again, I'm calling on Congress to give me a line-item veto for all government spending bills, and the Senate must end, they must end the filibuster rule and get down to work.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAPIRO: Now, political analysts have said, one, even if they had the filibuster removed from the Senate, they were missing John McCain. So the Republicans would not have had the majority that the President thinks that he might have been able to get.

The other issue, of course, was to DACA. The President wanted a fix that would have allowed the DACA students, roughly 800,000 people, to have 2.5 year extension in exchange for the Democrats fully funding the border wall with Mexico $25 billion. The Democrats wanted a permanent fix for the DACA students and other aliens who have come to the United States illegally and the President wouldn't do that because he wanted full funding for the border wall.

Here is what the President said about that situation in the negotiations of the omnibus.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: DACA recipients have been treated extremely badly by the Democrats. We wanted to include DACA. We wanted to have them in this bill. Eight hundred thousand people. And actually it could even be more.

And we wanted to include DACA in this bill. The Democrats would not do it. They would not do it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAPIRO: So Lauren, the President, although he doesn't say he got some of what the administration wanted in the bill, the biggest thing was rebuilding the U.S. Military. And as you heard at the beginning of the 2:00 hour, the President signed this bill, this $1.3 trillion bill, which he called ridiculous. He signed it for the sake of national security.

Back to you.

SIMONETTI: And the defense stocks certainly appreciating that today. They are up sharply. Adam, thank you very much.

SHAPIRO: Yes.

SIMONETTI: All right. Joining me now is the American Majority CEO, Ned Ryun, to talk about everything we just heard and everything that's gotten down the past 24 hours or so. Right now, we have averted a government shutdown. The question is, is that bad for Republicans because basically we control the White House and Congress as Republicans, and we just -- you had the President sign the second biggest spending bill ever, would a veto, Ned, have been worse? A government shutdown?

NED RYUN, CEO, AMERICAN MAJORITY: I actually think Trump was morally obligated to veto this omnibus bill. Let's not forget, Congress could have passed a short-term funding bill to keep the government open. This omnibus is a big government dream come true, and Trump, you know, two weeks ago, the President should have engaged more heavily.

The second best time was now veto the bill and start negotiating for a better deal on just a wide variety of fronts. I mean take away the names of those people that sign this, Republican Congress and the Republican President. This seems like we just went back to the future where this could be done by Obama and the Democrat Congress signing a $1.3 trillion bill to take our national debt to $22 trillion. It's hard to keep track of what our national debt is.

And the amazing thing to me in all of this, Lauren, is the facts that there was very little that Trump actually got. I know, he wants to promote the national security and the spending on the military, when it really comes down to it, the new funding for new wall is really just for about 33 feet of new wall. This is one of the biggest issues that he was elected on. And out of $1.3 trillion bill, we couldn't find $21billion to $25 billion to build the southern wall.

And the thing is, the social concern that I'm also deeply disappointed about in this omnibus, there's still over half a billion in annual funding for Planned Parenthood. I see very little to be happy about in this. And when it comes down to the military spending, Lauren, if he had vetoed this bill and forced them to actually negotiate and challenge them and dared them to not fund the military, he would have won that bet.

SIMONETTI: All right. Well, Ned, stay here. I also want to bring in the American University Scholar, Capri Cafaro joining us now.

Good to see you, Capri.

CAPRI CAFARO, AMERICAN UNIVERSITY SCHOLAR: Absolutely, anytime.

SIMONETTI: I want to talk to you about something that Senator Bob Corker tweeted. I love the tweet. He said, "Please do, Mr. President," meaning veto this bill. "I'm just down the street and will bring you the pen. The spending levels without any offsets are grotesque, throwing all of our children under the bus. Totally irresponsible."

Are we now having the President just sign a $1.3 trillion spending bill? Are we mortgaging millennials' futures? Are we killing our kids and grandkids?

CAFARO: Well, I mean, any time that you actually, you know, spend without offset, certainly, I mean, we're continuing to increase the deficit and debt. And I do think it's interesting, you know, Bob Corker and Rand Paul and many other, you know, stalwart Conservatives there, deficit hawks, certainly, are not excited about a $1.3 trillion spending bill, regardless what's in it. And so, I think, that this is a fundamental discussion amongst the nuances and the branches of the Republican Party.

Donald Trump has never been an ideological purist, and whether it is, you know, his issues with trade and tariffs or, you know, these kind of things.

SIMONETTI: Yes.

CAFARO: I mean, he basically said, "I might veto this bill because, number one, it doesn't have more spending and, number two, per the DACA recipients. So, you know, if you are a Freedom Caucus guy, you scratch your head.

SIMONETTI: He's all about the negotiation, Ned. He's all about the art of the deal and the compromise. So he basically said as I saw it, Ned, "I'll give you what you want on DACA. You give me what I want on my wall." But neither seemed happen?

RYUN: No, neither seemed happen. This is why I'm a little perplexed as to how this all went down when neither party walked away with what they wanted.

Lauren, Trump ran on, I am going to come to Washington. It will not be business as usual. I will drain the swamp. We will shake up D.C.

What we saw today is business as usual. The swamp on the rise. We did not see anything that he ran on in 2016. And people like me were voting for an outside the box candidate, and what you saw today with him signing this bill.

And, again, Democrats didn't get DACA. He didn't get his wall. We got $1.3 trillion. The taxpayers got saddled with $1.3 trillion extra in spending. I'm perplexed as to what we actually voted for in 2016, because right now what we're seeing is nothing what we expected on that campaign just a year and a half ago.

SIMONETTI: Yes. And, you know, I'll give you the final answer here, Capri. I asked Ned this question earlier, should the President just have let the government shutdown over this?

CAFARO: I don't think so. I think that that would have been irresponsible. You know, they're on recess.

I think it's important that, you know, you move the ball forward, and I think he actually framed this very well actually for the 2018 midterms. He tried to blame Democrats for overspending and he sent a very strong message to Washington, to Congress saying, "We want a certain number of kind of procedural reforms." So I think he's setting the stage saying, "Never again. I'm going let this go, and if you don't do XYZ, there is a going to be wrath.

SIMONETTI: You've been warned. All right. Capri, Ned, thank you to both of you. Have a good weekend.

RYUN: Thanks Laura.

SIMONETTI: All right. Let's turn back to the chaotic markets. Right now, stocks are higher. Paring gains, we did hit session highs on President Trump's decision to sign the $1.3 trillion spending bill in order to fund the military the way they need and to keep the government open. Right now, Dow industrials up 74 points. The week has been terrible.

Let's bring in Vision 4 Fund Distributors Vice President, Heather Zumarraga, along Tematica Research CIO, Chris Versace.

Good to see you, Heather and Chris.

HEATHER ZUMARRAGA, VICE PRESIDENT, VISION 4 FUND DISTRIBUTORS: Hi.

CHRIS VERSACE, CIO, TEMATICA RESEARCH CIO: Thanks for having me.

SIMONETTI: You know, they say it's been a chaotic few days for the markets. Heather, let me ask you first. What do you think investors are responding to most, the fact we are keeping national debt at astronomical levels and only growing it or growing trade war?

ZUMARRAGA: I think a growing trade war. Investors are responding to that more. I know that we're rallying on the backs of the announcement that President Trump is not going to veto the spending bill, Lauren. But I think trade is still a wild card in the markets right now.

We really don't know the details of final legislation, and so how will that impact the industrials, the materials, the metals, even technology. I think that we'll still weigh on investors' minds and there's more downside to come. But the fundamentals are still in place, earnings are up, inflation remains low and unemployment is low. So, that's great.

SIMONETTI: Chris, we had a lot of guests on the show yesterday when the market was down 724 points at the end of the day, and they were kind of saying, yes, this is no big deal, this is all part of the negotiation of the President. We think when you take a scalpel to these tariffs, we're going to exempt the right people and everybody can just breathe a sigh of relief. And in a sense, they were right today, and I point out Boeing shares. Boeing is responsible for most of the Dow's climb. Is that signaling to you that everything might be OK in the end as we're gambling with U.S. versus China versus the rest of the world?

VERSACE: Yes, I think what you're seeing is usual stock market, you know, shoot first, ask questions later.

SIMONETTI: Yes.

VERSACE: You know, when you look at the data that we're getting, we saw the March Flash PMI come out, you know, signaling an improvement in the economy. I think the big issue that people are getting caught up in is, you know, demand is improving but the question is, what's the cost structure going to be? And I think, that's what getting people a little nervous. You know, if we do see these tariffs going into effect, obviously, steel, aluminum will move higher. If the response into effect, other costs could move higher as well.

And remember, we're getting ready for the March-quarter earnings season where the markets predicated on 18 percent to 20 percent EPS bump for the S&P 500 this year. If that story starts to come undone a little bit, it likely means the market will give some ground back. So I think what you're seeing now is the market getting prepared for that potential conversation, but there are still strong well-positioned companies out there. Perhaps we can buy them now at even better prices.

SIMONETTI: So, Heather, should we buy more domestic companies. Fewer multinationals. And I say that because, what, Nike gets 15 percent of its revenue from China, right?

ZUMARRAGA: Yes.

SIMONETTI: Starbucks, about the same percentage from China. And if we have a different relationship with China, maybe our big companies need to rethink their strategy in order to keep their earnings strong?

ZUMARRAGA: Yes, you're right. Over the short term, I think you can look at smaller cap companies based in the U.S., Russell 2000 is a good gauge of small cap companies, that aren't heavily impacted of potential trade wars or China retaliation of our tariffs. And so these global multinational companies would be impacted the most.

I just don't think it makes sense right now to place a bet on a direction long or short on a global multinational when we don't have the final details. Go to Vegas.

SIMONETTI: We don't know.

ZUMARRAGA: Yes, you'd be better off.

SIMONETTI: No, that's an excellent point. And, Chris, maybe you can help explain to me how tariffs on, let's say, solar panels, washing machines and steel deal with the Chinese theft of our trade secrets, our technology, our intellectual property?

ZUMARRAGA: They do.

VERSACE: I would like to be able to say that but I know the answer to that, but those are two are very different things. I mean, you know, when we talk about, you know, the tariffs in a way to help support our national security and prevent issues from happening, I think, a lot of people can get behind that. I think when we talk about washing machines, solar panels and the other things where we're going to see costs driven up, I think people, they get caught in the crosshairs a little bit understanding that we want to buy American but we also have economy that's predicated on cash strapped consumers trying to spend and spend more, which means we need cheaper alternatives. Hence, some of these goods coming in that we've been relying upon from China.

So, it's an interesting Catch-22, but I think the long-term question is if we can get our capacity in the U.S. up to meet demands, get better pricing, then we can get better paying jobs in the U.S. and help continue the rebound in the economy.

SIMONETTI: Heather, you talked about this earlier, and I'm not going to -- I agree with you. Employment situation is looking better, corporate earnings are strong, the economic data has been good. But when you look at numbers, last year GDP in the U.S. averaged 2.3 percent. Guess what it averaged in China? Six point nine percent. They transitioned from a made- in-China economy to a made-for-China economy, and we need to stop that.

ZUMARRAGA: Yes, they're still trying transition to consumption economy in China. And, look, the data that comes out of China in terms of GDP, I never really -- you don't know if you can trust the data that's coming out of China. They always seem to meet or beat their GDP forecast. So, it's always looking rosy over in China.

But, look, they need us as much as we need them. We import about $500 billion of stuff from them every year, and although there is a massive trade deficit, we don't want to hurt China. In the end, we just want more, fair playing field, and that's what we're going after. I'm just not sure tariffs are the best way to do it.

SIMONETTI: And arguably, who needs who more than the other? Heather, Chris, I guess, we don't have all the answers today. Thank you so much.

ZUMARRAGA: You got it.

SIMONETTI: Have a great weekend.

ZUMARRAGA: You, too.

SIMONETTI: Well, President Trump is signing the massive spending bill today saying he'll do it for national security. This, as he names former U.S. Ambassador to the U.N. John Bolton as his next National Security Adviser. Ambassador Bolton is a foreign policy hawk when it comes to issues like Iran and North Korea. So how is all of this going to play out on the world stage? We're going to discuss that with Retired Four-star General Jack Keane, in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

SIMONETTI: Final day of a tough week at the office. We've got less than two hours left and the markets are all in the negative. The Dow is down two points. If we're lower today, we're -- this will be the third day of losses in a row and pretty significant losses at that. S&P is down 11 points and the NASDAQ selling off the most here on percentage terms by almost three-quarters of one percent.

Just moments ago, the President invokes national security in his reason for signing the $1.3 trillion spending bill vowing that our military will be the strongest ever, defense stocks rallying on this.

He also tapped Former Ambassador and Fox News Contributor, John Bolton, as his new and third National Security Adviser. Bolton was known for having hawkish positions on Iran and North Korea. And earlier today, he told Stuart Varney this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN BOLTON, INCOMING NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISER: I think my view is the same as the President's, which he's described as the worst deal in American diplomatic history. The issue for any deal like this is are you really solving the problem or you just simply making people feel good while a country like Iran violates its commitments?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: The President had kind words for his Outgoing National Security Adviser, H.R. McMaster tweeting, I'm very thankful for the service of General McMaster who has done an outstanding job and will always remain my friend.

Joining me now, Fox News Senior Strategic Analyst, General Jack Keane. What do you make of all this, General?

GEN. JACK KEANE (RET.), FOX NEWS SENIOR STRATEGIC ANALYST: Well, I think what's the hardest thing about government and particularly Executive branches everybody starts a job that they've never had before on the same day. And now the President's a year plus into his job, and I think he understands the presidency now, he understands his role. He knows what he's bringing to the table. What strengths and weaknesses. And he kind of knows what he wants from the staff and also from his Cabinet officials, that's why he's making these changes, because --

SIMONETTI: So it seems like --

KEANE: -- he knows what he wants.

SIMONETTI: It seems like chaos in the White House is really just growing pains and now he's got the team in place that he wants.

KEANE: Yes, pretty much.

SIMONETTI: OK.

KEANE: I don't think he's finished yet, but it is pretty -- and I think when you look at, you know, Mike Pompeo over at State and --

SIMONETTI: Yes.

KEANE: -- and Kudlow in as Economic Adviser and John Bolton, all three of these people I know and have great respect for them, they're going fit right like a hand in a glove with what the President is thinking. They won't agree with him on everything and I don't think the President necessarily wants that. But he clearly wants someone who is going to get right behind his agenda and support it.

And, you know, if you spend so much time around these people, you kind of want to like them as well.

SIMONETTI: Yes, let's talk about John Bolton. Because he is known as being a military action type of guy, definitely hawkish when it comes to foreign policy. He'll start officially in April, which is interesting because in May, the President is expected to decide the fate of the Iran nuclear deal and he's also expected to meet with the leader of North Korea. How do you think John Bolton will affect any of those decisions and meetings?

KEANE: Well, first of all, Bolton agrees with the President's national security strategy. We're turning to a big power competition, again, with Russia, China, Iran, rogue state like North Korea who was nuclearizing ICBM's and is threatening the American people. So Bolton's approach to that, as is the President's approach, is to stand up to it not to confront it. All those countries we're talking about.

SIMONETTI: All right.

KEANE: Not to appease these countries as the previous administration has done, which has weakened the relationship that our allies have with each other and also with us and is emboldened our adversaries. So, if you want the diplomatic situation to work effectively, our adversary has to know that we're at least willing to use a military option if it's necessary and that's what the President has been trying to convince Kim Jong-un of for a year plus now.

"Yes, I'm imposing economic sanctions on you, but I'm also wanting to use a military option if those sanctions fail." And I think Bolton will come in and reinforce that very solidly along with the rest of the national security team.

SIMONETTI: He just -- in the end of February, wrote an op-ed in "The Wall Street Journal" basically saying talking doesn't work. The title of this article was "The Legal Case for Striking North Korea First." So we know who's in charge here and what we're playing with.

The other issue, and this is something Mr. Bolton certainly knows, is that North Korea often makes you think they're willing to negotiate when really they're just trying to buy themselves time to further develop or hide their weapons.

KEANE: Well, that certainly has been the pattern for 25 years.

SIMONETTI: Yes.

KEANE: In other words, the goal with the negotiations, they buy some time, they advance their technology and they get concessions. We don't know for sure whether these negotiations are sincere or they're phony like the others. But we're going to find out here pretty quick.

SIMONETTI: And what about Russia? It seems like Mr. Bolton and the President have different -- Trump has been criticized for appeasing or overlooking some of the things that Russia does. And it seems Mr. Bolton would have a more hard line on Russia?

KEANE: I think so. Most of us take a harder line dealing with Russia than the President has on all of these issues. And now, he has stood up to Russia to be sure. He is providing lethal aid to the Ukrainian, something the previous administration never did.

He struck Assad's air power 36 hours after they used chemical weapons, and those chemical weapons had passive approval of the Russians in doing that, you know, who is a client state of Russia. And clearly we're now sanctioning Russia. But I agree, I think what the President is in his head with this thing, I think, it's a mistake to think he is soft on Russia, because I don't buy that.

I think what he believes himself is that -- he's itching to get into the room with Putin. And the reason for that is he knows that Putin has manipulated his three predecessors quite successfully. And I think he believes, "You know, I've dealt with people like this before, I know where he's coming from. I know he's a thug and a bully, but I'm not going to say that in public because I don't want to forfeit my ability to have a real conversation with this guy." I think that's where the President's head really is. And we'll see.

SIMONETTI: Well said, General Keane. Thank you very much.

KEANE: OK. Good talking to you, Lauren.

SIMONETTI: All right. Have a great weekend.

All right. Let's take a look at this market before we all head out for the weekend. You can see down across the board here, S&P is down half of one percent. NASDAQ is down three-quarters of one percent.

We're going live to the New York Stock Exchange next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

SIMONETTI: And while the Dow is below 24,000, stocks turning negative amid a very choppy session as investors weigh the impact of Congress' trillion plus dollar spending bill and also a looming trade war with China. We go to Nicole Petallides at the New York Stock Exchange for a rundown of the chaotic action today.

Nicole, how are you?

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Right, Lauren. Just to name a few of the items here front and center on Wall Street with every headline that comes our way, the Dow is down about a thousand points this week and yesterday's close of more than 700 points to the downside. It was about 100 points off of that low in early February. The hope is not to take out that low and, in fact, try and keep that as a support level.

Looking at the Dow right now down 11 points had been down 124 points, up just about 50. So we're watching to see where we end. But for the week the Dow and the S&P are down about four percent, the NASDAQ down five percent. Defense stocks though bucking the trend.

We've had so much news, of course, Bolton now the National Security Adviser. He's hawkish. The idea that he's going to be spending on our national security, you can see Lockheed Martin, Northrop Grumman up about four percent each. This group as a group in aerospace and defense group is seeing it the best day jumping since President Trump was elected to be our President in November of 2016.

And a quick look at the big tech IPO of the day. That's Dropbox in the Cloud-based file storage area. Look at this, up 40 percent. This is the largest IPO since Snap, Lauren, and it certainly saw the demand even though that IPO price was raised, it's still jumping. It seems everybody is trying to get in on this particular tech stock, and it's a winner today.

Back to you.

SIMONETTI: Yes. Big tech is struggling, Nicole. And this is, you know, they call them the unicorns. Maybe this is the next thing. We'll see. Nicole, thank you.

Well, China is certainly firing back today. They are threatening retaliatory tariffs on $3 billion worth of U.S. goods, this, after President Trump announced new tariffs on Chinese goods. So are we headed for an all-out trade war? How bad does it get? We've got the intel next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

SIMONETTI: Well, ISIS claiming responsibility for today's hostage situation in France. National police there say, at least, three people were killed and a dozen wounded in what is being described as a terrorist attack. The armed gunman, who was shot and killed by police, demanding the release of one of the Paris attackers from the 2015 Bataclan massacre.

And video surfacing, and this is hard to watch, of the fatal pedestrian crash that involved self-driving Uber car. Well, the 22-second clip shows a woman walking from a dark area onto the street with her bicycle before the SUV hits her. Experts say the vehicle sensors should have spotted her. Her name was Elaine Herzberg. She was 49 years old.

But the video also shows the driver was distracted. He's called a minder. He's just operating the self-driving car. We're also learning he was a convicted felon.

And the parents out there, Toys "R" Us officially kicking off the going out of business sale today. All 735 stores, including Babies "R" Us, the company is not saying how big the discounts will be and obviously there are no returns here. Customers will be able to use their gift cards until April 21st. But that is the death of an iconic store.

All right. Back to the main story today. China threatening to impose its own reciprocal tariffs on American goods just one day after President Trump announced plans to slap steep tariffs on Chinese goods. Stoking fears that this might be the beginning of an all-out trade war. All of this as the President's broad-based steel and aluminum tariffs kicked in today. And the President's demand a pretty simple, he wants free and fair trade with China.

Here he is speaking just moments ago at the White House.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: China is going to end up treating us fairly. For many years, they had free reign, they don't have free reign anymore. We're very friendly with China. We have great relationships with China. And, look, it's time. It's time.

Last year, we lost $500 billion on trade with China. We can't let that happen. And thank you all very much.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: All right. Joining me now is Manhattan Institute Senior Fellow, Steven Malanga. Good to see you, Steve.

STEVEN MALANGA, MANHATTAN SENIOR INSTITUTE FELLOW: Hi. How are you?

SIMONETTI: So, no matter what number you use, $375 billion, $504 billion most of our global trade deficit at $800 is with China.

MALANGA: Yes. So--

SIMONETTI: How do you fix this?

MALANGA: -- all the lost is strange here. Well, look I think that even most free traders will tell you that there's imbalance because China cheats. China has -- our agreements with them are, in a sense, unfair. They demand technology from our companies --

SIMONETTI: Yes.

MALANGA: -- in order for some companies to go over this, we have to move jobs over there.

SIMONETTI: Set up a joint venture with them. You can't own more than 49 percent of their companies.

MALANGA: They ban of our countries' companies. Facebook can't operate there. Of course after the data breach, I doubt they will. They don't have to forget about.

SIMONETTI: We'll talk about that later.

MALANGA: Right. So there's no doubt.

SIMONETTI: Right.

MALANGA: But the real question that people have is whether Trump has an actual strategy here, a coherent strategy.

SIMONETTI: Does he?

MALANGA: Well, it's inconsistent. First of all, this is an administration that back in 2017 was saying -- Wilbur Ross, for instance, was saying that we're not going to have to be punitive. We're going to negotiate with China, and they're already on board with this.

The President himself who called China a currency manipulator during his campaign, he's not declared China a manipulator. Now all of a sudden, we're being punitive and it seems it come out of nowhere and even the Chinese are a little bit confused. So, people are kind of wondering what's going on and whether he has a strategy.

SIMONETTI: And it seems like the tariffs so far on steel and aluminum, on the washing machines, it seems like they're not addressing the problem. The main problem is China's theft of our intellectual property.

MALANGA: Well, that's exactly right. Again, there's the sense. First of all, people don't know whether when he basically said, "OK, look, we're going to slap the tariffs on." And then he pulled them back on Canada and Mexico, whether they had actually planned that or whether they just said, "oops!" you know, now our trading partners are getting upset with us.

But the real question, I'll give you an example, OK. Trump, one of the ways that you want to increase an imbalance like this is basically to create more opportunities for American companies.

The Trans-Pacific Partnership was going to be an opportunity. It wasn't a well-negotiated trade deal, OK? But there was a chance to make that better and to create opportunities with Asian trading partners in opposition for China. Instead Trump just said, "We're going to abandon it, we're done with it." That, you see --

SIMONETTI: Do you think we get back into it on different terms?

MALANGA: -- yes, definitely on different terms, but thing is you had a framework, you had a negotiation, go forward with that. So, listen, it's not adequate enough, we're still on the losing end with you folks but we all need to be united against China. But that's not what the President did. So, that's where he's sending mixed messages.

SIMONETTI: Do you think we're starting to align as we do, you know, team Washington versus team Beijing here? You see these tariffs with many exemptions. The E.U and six other countries, one of them being South Korea, they're exempt from some of these tariffs. But let me ask you this, South Korea is exempt, most of Europe is exempt, those markets tanked today?

MALANGA: Well, the interesting thing is, you know, on the list of potential currency manipulators are South Korea, Japan, Germany, and European Union. So they're grouped in there with China, OK. There's no -- we have imbalances, OK?

We have with other countries too, where we essentially allow them more access to our markets than they allow us to their markets. Trump is right to focus on that. There's nothing wrong with that. But the point is whether a trade war in which he seems to be picking his targets and then pulling back, he's sending mixed messages to people rather than getting out and then create more -- demanding more opportunity for American companies overseas. That's absolutely a strategy.

SIMONETTI: Does all of this create American jobs in the end or does it just hurt the American work of vis-a-vis higher consumer prices?

MALANGA: Well, here is the thing, one of the ironies of this right now is that we have almost record low unemployment. Usually you start trade wars.

SIMONETTI: And we're down 3.6 percent --

MALANGA: Exactly.

SIMONETTI: -- according to the Fed.

MALANGA: And here is the thing, right, if you walk right now, OK --

SIMONETTI: Yes.

MALANGA: -- have companies who can't find enough workers, right, because they have opportunities and we don't have people trained for that. If you really wanted to move forward with opportunity right now, the one thing you would be looking, actually, is getting people better trained to take those jobs that are open in our own marketplace right now.

SIMONETTI: All right. Steve, good to see you. Thank you very much. All right.

Let's see if Steve moved the markets, because they've been all over the place today. Every body has moved on. Dow is down 43 points at 23,917.

The other markets are lower as well. All of this as Dropbox, we were a little bit nervous about this this morning when the futures were tanking 200. They made their debut on the NASDAQ. We're going to have more on all of this in just a bit.

Look at Dropbox shares rallying 40 percent on day one.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

SIMONETTI: Take a look at shares of Dropbox, surging on their first day of trading. The company launching its IPO amid a firestorm of economic news. Currently wreaking havoc in Washington and on Wall Street. Look at that, Dropbox priced at 21. Opened we get 29, it's at 29.46 a pop now.

Let's go to the floor of the New York Stock Exchange where Virtu Financial trader, Matt Cheslock, joins us now.

All right. So, you know, Dropbox not trading where you are, it's at the NASDAQ, but it's a unicorn, right? It's a start-up. It has a billion dollars in revenue right now. Valued at about $8, $9 billion.

Pales in comparison to somebody's huge big textile, all are Amazon and Netflix, and Alphabet. They're not holding up so well as we get all the big tech company. But investors are still optimistic on tech?

MATT CHESLOCK, VIRTU FINANCIAL TRADER: Yes, you know what? I mean this was a good barometer for what the market was looking for. So, maybe you have the sell-off in the tech sector, maybe they were raising money to buy Dropbox. I mean, it was 25 times oversubscribed, right? So, it had a tremendous day that despite the market closing down 700 yesterday.

There had to be worries last night going in to price on that deal, but they came out through and smelled like roses here. So, you know, all good from there. And, you know, just an example of, you know, what there is on the tech side. You know, there are so many of these unicorns that are waiting to see some money and go public to get the investors involved.

SIMONETTI: You know, we're looking at the Dow and it is now down in triple digits once again. We're not seeing a recovery. Of course, anything can happen in this final hour and 10 minutes here. But we're riding 724-point sell-off yesterday. What gives?

CHESLOCK: You know what? I would've rather seen a sharp sell-off this morning and have us recover throughout the day. Instead we tried to open higher and it failed. We tried multiple times during the day.

Whatever we can take out of Washington as a positive, you know, the spending bill that should have been a foregone conclusion, it wasn't even talked about yesterday. The only fact that really was mentioned today was because it was almost got vetoed. So, other than that, you know, there hasn't been all lot out there. It's good stock specific.

You know, company like Nike and company like Boeing today, you know, they're performing pretty well outside of the Dropbox.

SIMONETTI: Yes. Boeing is, well, they are --

CHESLOKCK: Good work.

SIMONETTI: -- a positive contribution today. Does that make you feel -- because Boeing is such a multinational, Asia and China are such a big part of its business, does that encourage you that maybe this trade war won't get so bad the way Boeing is performing?

CHESLOCK: Yes, you know, the fact they weren't mentioned in this first round of the $3 billion, you know, tit-for-tat here. So, you know, but eventually that's going to be leveraged. Once you start to bring in Boeing specifically, that may start bringing the U.S at the table a little bit quicker and maybe we have some real dialogue and we can get down to this.

We all know that the U.S. doesn't benefit from a trade war but we also don't benefit anyway from the trade right now. So, we need to get on equal footing or somewhat equal footing, so this negotiation is a long way from over but, you know, at least now we have a starting point.

SIMONETTI: All right. Matt, thank you very much.

CHESLOCK: Sure.

SIMONETTI: All right. Breaking today, Congress has formally asked Facebook CEO, Mark Zuckerberg, to testify about the company's misuse of your data. And shares of Facebook are lower today. Killed on the week.

Double digit percentage declines as the Delete Facebook movement gains steam. Is this the end for Facebook? Are you going to delete your Facebook page?

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

SIMONETTI: Let's take a look at the sell-off on Wall Street. Dow is down 113 points as we head into the final hour of trading. Financials getting killed the most today.

Meanwhile, Congress has formally asked CEO of Facebook, Mark Zuckerberg, to testify about what the company is doing to protect user data and privacy. This, after it was revealed that the data firm Cambridge Analytica may have improperly gain access to data of million, 50 million Facebook users.

Joining me now, our very own, Deirdre Bolton, along with Founder of Disruptive Tech Research, Lou Basenese.

Deirdre, do you think people are really going to delete Facebook? We know that Elon Musk has.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: I was just going to say, if you want to one person, Elon Musk, he actually was kind of funny about it. I swear that he got nothing, he was like, oh, yes, I didn't even realize that SpaceX or Tesla had their own pages, 2.5 million --

SIMONETTI: On each.

BOLTON: -- on each. So, and they said, oh, yes, this looks kind of lame. I'll just have to delete it anyway. So, yes, basically 5 million gone -- users gone from Facebook. So he is keeping his Instagram account, I guess he should underline that, and as we know Facebook owns Instagram. But, he says that he doesn't feel that Facebook's influence is creeping in, those are his words, not mine, into the Instagram account as much for which he has about 7 million followers.

But, I do think this underlines -- this is the real business risk for Facebook is that OK, this is kind of funny, it's Elon Musk, it's one person but he has Tesla, he has SpaceX, he's widely followed as an entrepreneur. And just the idea that maybe Facebook becomes less cool, less usable and this Delete Facebook has actually gained some traction.

On the other side, it has more than 2 billion users. A lot of people use it, a lot of even older people to see pictures of grandkids, people who have family members overseas. So, it doesn't go away so easily either.

SIMONETTI: Even to date, Lou, if you're on tinder and you most likely need a Facebook account, they kind of go hand-in-hand. It's so ingrained in our society.

LOUIS BASENESE, FOUNDER; DISRUPTIVE TECH RESEARCH: Yes, it is. I think Facebook widely recognized long ago that they needed to have their tentacles into our lives across multiple platforms. And like Deirdre said, there's Instagram, there's Facebook Messenger. They found ways to make it much harder to delete Facebook.

And, you know, I would tell you, I think the biggest risk here, the Delete Facebook movement is definitely a risk, but the biggest risk here comes from advertisers. If they protest and bail en masse, then the business falls apart. And, you know, I think that's a low probability, ironically because Facebook's data on its users is so good and its scale is so big, over 2 billion users, advertisers aren't going to give up that marketing channel.

So, you know, look, I think we said this earlier in the week, Lauren, this, too, shall pass for Facebook, but this nightmare is far from over. There's going to be a lot of questions to be answered in uncomfortable situations for the CEO.

BOLTON: Indeed, and it's also a business problem as we've talked about, too, in the sense that Facebook has to decide are we actually going to spend more money to get human engineers who cost money, who want vacations, who want personal time? But they probably need to hire a lot of people to make sure that these data infractions aren't repeated.

I want a message as well or let you know about this message that we got from Cambridge Analytica. The acting CEO says the data that had been obtained from Facebook was in line with Facebook's term of service and data protection laws. So that's a pretty -- and basically, Cambridge Analytica is saying, hey, listen, we didn't do anything wrong. We were following the map, if you like, that Facebook set out.

BASENESE: Right.

BOLTON: So that's going to be one of the conversations that's continued, to your point Lou, in D.C. and Mark Zuckerberg, is going to have to, I mean, the New York A.G. has started an investigation, the Massachusetts A.G., has started an investigation.

SIMONETTI: I know.

BOLTON: Senators Thune, Nelson, saying, listen, Mark Zuckerberg, you need to come here to D.C., you need to tell us --

SIMONETTI: And overseas there are investigations resume --

BOLTON: -- the U.K.

SIMONETTI: The Dow just fell about 200 points. And typically, Lou, we've seen the big tech companies, the so-called fang stocks recovered pretty quickly when there's a big sell-off. We're not seeing that this time around. What do you make of that?

BASENESE: I'm not too concern of that, I think this is the trickle-down effects from the regulatory threats that are facing Facebook, right? You've already had some Congress representatives calling in potentially other CEOs from tech companies to talk about regulating their data. I mean, this is just turning into a short-term debacle for Facebook, and it's spilling over into the larger tech stocks.

I think if you want to look for protection, you've got to go somewhere into the small and micro cap land that are largely insulated from all of this. But right now, the headline of the day is going to be the breach of user trust and, you know, there's an old ancient Jewish scholar that once said, be careful, your sins will find you out. And Facebook is learning that the hard way right now. Like Cambridge, Deirdre just share, the Cambridge CEO has pointing their finger at Facebook saying, hey, we didn't do anything wrong, you're the one that originally sent here gave us access to the user data. And it's going to be really hard to restore trust when users know that that was given so freely.

SIMONETTI: One story that just is not going away because it implicates regulation and other companies as well. Lou, Deirdre, thank you so much for your perspective today.

BASENESE: Thank you.

SIMONETTI: And that is it for me, but you can watch me every weekday, 5 a.m. Eastern on the Fox Business Network.

Now, Ashley Webster is in for Liz Claman. And Ashley?

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Yes. Here we go again.

SIMONETTI: Lock and load.

WEBSTER: TGIF.

SIMONETTI: There you go.

WEBSTER: But we had a big sell-off and here we are an hour to go before the bell rings that brings to the end, a very ugly week. Lauren Simonetti, thank you very much.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RY3-8021-DXH2-61PP-00000-00Trump Signs Spending Bill; McMaster Out, Bolton In; Trump Taps Bolton as NSA; China Threatens to Retaliate after President Trump Imposed Tariffs on Chinese Goods; ISIS Claims France Attack; Trump Gets Tough on China; Facebook Under Fire; Stocks at Session Lows2018-03-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:08ZLexisNexisINTELLIGENCE REPORT2:00 PM ESTNed Ryun, Capri Cafaro, Heather Zumarraga, Chris Versace, John Bolton, Steven Malanga, Matt Cheslock, Lou BaseneseNEWSFinancial032301cb.232Trump Signs Spending Bill; McMaster Out, Bolton In; Trump Taps Bolton as NSA; China Threatens to Retaliate after President Trump Imposed Tariffs on Chinese Goods; ISIS Claims France Attack; Trump Gets Tough on China; Facebook Under Fire; Stocks at Session LowsLauren Simonetti, Adam Shapiro, Jack Keane, Nicole Petallides, Deirdre Bolton

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: And breaking right now, everybody, it is official, President Trump signing Congress' newly passed, nearly $1.5 trillion spending bill and he just called it ridiculous, all this as the markets, quite frankly, all over the place today. Right now, we are near session highs for the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 137 points. What a Friday.

Thank you for joining us. I'm Lauren Simonetti. I'm in for Trish Regan and welcome to THE INTELLIGENCE REPORT. Well, President Trump shaking Capitol Hill today threatening to veto the spending bill saying it didn't spend enough on his border wall. Then he said he would sign it but never anything like it ever, ever again.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: As a matter of national security, I've signed this omnibus budget bill. There are a lot of things that's I'm unhappy about in this bill. There are a lot of things that we shouldn't have had in this bill but we were, in a sense, forced if we want to build our military. We were forced to have.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: We're going to have more on that straight ahead.

And stocks, as we've noted, down sharply. Yesterday, down in the pre- market. Guess what? They opened higher today but moments after President Trump threatened to veto the omnibus bill came, the markets retreated, went negative then they bounced back again as we learned that the President would sign the spending bill. It's so crazy.

We also have fears of a trade war. They continue today as China now threatens to retaliate after President Trump imposed about $60 billion on tariffs on Chinese goods. What does this mean for the world's two largest economies? We're on that story as well.

But first, we go to Adam Shapiro who is live at the White House with the latest on the spending bill. Adam the guessing game is now over?

ADAM SHAPIRO, FOX BUSINESS REPORTER: The guessing game is over, and you heard the President say he did this for the sake of national security. You heard Defense Secretary Mattis talking about this and this is the largest military spending in U.S. history to help rebuild the nation's military and secure the national defense. But the President is not pleased because, as he said as he was leaving the diplomatic room at the White House, that he very seriously considered a veto because while the administration got some of what it wanted, this didn't fix DACA and he had a message to Hispanic- Americans saying, "Republicans are working in your interest better than Democrats." He was very upset with this.

And as you have -- in the introduction, the sound bite in which he said he would never sign a bill like this again, one way to avoid that, he said, would be to revoke the filibuster the Senate has. Here is the President in his own words.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: To prevent the omnibus situation from ever happening again, I'm calling on Congress to give me a line-item veto for all government spending bills, and the Senate must end, they must end the filibuster rule and get down to work.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAPIRO: Now, political analysts have said, one, even if they had the filibuster removed from the Senate, they were missing John McCain. So the Republicans would not have had the majority that the President thinks that he might have been able to get.

The other issue, of course, was to DACA. The President wanted a fix that would have allowed the DACA students, roughly 800,000 people, to have 2.5 year extension in exchange for the Democrats fully funding the border wall with Mexico $25 billion. The Democrats wanted a permanent fix for the DACA students and other aliens who have come to the United States illegally and the President wouldn't do that because he wanted full funding for the border wall.

Here is what the President said about that situation in the negotiations of the omnibus.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: DACA recipients have been treated extremely badly by the Democrats. We wanted to include DACA. We wanted to have them in this bill. Eight hundred thousand people. And actually it could even be more.

And we wanted to include DACA in this bill. The Democrats would not do it. They would not do it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAPIRO: So Lauren, the President, although he doesn't say he got some of what the administration wanted in the bill, the biggest thing was rebuilding the U.S. Military. And as you heard at the beginning of the 2:00 hour, the President signed this bill, this $1.3 trillion bill, which he called ridiculous. He signed it for the sake of national security.

Back to you.

SIMONETTI: And the defense stocks certainly appreciating that today. They are up sharply. Adam, thank you very much.

SHAPIRO: Yes.

SIMONETTI: All right. Joining me now is the American Majority CEO, Ned Ryun, to talk about everything we just heard and everything that's gotten down the past 24 hours or so. Right now, we have averted a government shutdown. The question is, is that bad for Republicans because basically we control the White House and Congress as Republicans, and we just -- you had the President sign the second biggest spending bill ever, would a veto, Ned, have been worse? A government shutdown?

NED RYUN, CEO, AMERICAN MAJORITY: I actually think Trump was morally obligated to veto this omnibus bill. Let's not forget, Congress could have passed a short-term funding bill to keep the government open. This omnibus is a big government dream come true, and Trump, you know, two weeks ago, the President should have engaged more heavily.

The second best time was now veto the bill and start negotiating for a better deal on just a wide variety of fronts. I mean take away the names of those people that sign this, Republican Congress and the Republican President. This seems like we just went back to the future where this could be done by Obama and the Democrat Congress signing a $1.3 trillion bill to take our national debt to $22 trillion. It's hard to keep track of what our national debt is.

And the amazing thing to me in all of this, Lauren, is the facts that there was very little that Trump actually got. I see very little to be happy about in this. And when it comes down to the military spending, Lauren, if he had vetoed this bill and forced them to actually negotiate and challenge them and dared them to not fund the military, he would have won that bet.

SIMONETTI: All right. Matt, thank you very much.

CHESLOCK: Sure.

SIMONETTI: All right. Breaking today, Congress has formally asked Facebook CEO, Mark Zuckerberg, to testify about the company's misuse of your data. And shares of Facebook are lower today. Killed on the week.

Double digit percentage declines as the Delete Facebook movement gains steam. Is this the end for Facebook? Are you going to delete your Facebook page?

SIMONETTI: Let's take a look at the sell-off on Wall Street. Dow is down 113 points as we head into the final hour of trading. Financials getting killed the most today.

Meanwhile, Congress has formally asked CEO of Facebook, Mark Zuckerberg, to testify about what the company is doing to protect user data and privacy. This, after it was revealed that the data firm Cambridge Analytica may have improperly gain access to data of million, 50 million Facebook users.

Joining me now, our very own, Deirdre Bolton, along with Founder of Disruptive Tech Research, Lou Basenese.

Deirdre, do you think people are really going to delete Facebook? We know that Elon Musk has.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: I was just going to say, if you want to one person, Elon Musk, he actually was kind of funny about it. I swear that he got nothing, he was like, oh, yes, I didn't even realize that SpaceX or Tesla had their own pages, 2.5 million --

SIMONETTI: On each.

BOLTON: -- on each. So, and they said, oh, yes, this looks kind of lame. I'll just have to delete it anyway. So, yes, basically 5 million gone -- users gone from Facebook. So he is keeping his Instagram account, I guess he should underline that, and as we know Facebook owns Instagram. But, he says that he doesn't feel that Facebook's influence is creeping in, those are his words, not mine, into the Instagram account as much for which he has about 7 million followers.

But, I do think this underlines -- this is the real business risk for Facebook is that OK, this is kind of funny, it's Elon Musk, it's one person but he has Tesla, he has SpaceX, he's widely followed as an entrepreneur. And just the idea that maybe Facebook becomes less cool, less usable and this Delete Facebook has actually gained some traction.

On the other side, it has more than 2 billion users. A lot of people use it, a lot of even older people to see pictures of grandkids, people who have family members overseas. So, it doesn't go away so easily either.

SIMONETTI: Even to date, Lou, if you're on tinder and you most likely need a Facebook account, they kind of go hand-in-hand. It's so ingrained in our society.

LOUIS BASENESE, FOUNDER; DISRUPTIVE TECH RESEARCH: Yes, it is. I think Facebook widely recognized long ago that they needed to have their tentacles into our lives across multiple platforms. And like Deirdre said, there's Instagram, there's Facebook Messenger. They found ways to make it much harder to delete Facebook.

And, you know, I would tell you, I think the biggest risk here, the Delete Facebook movement is definitely a risk, but the biggest risk here comes from advertisers. If they protest and bail en masse, then the business falls apart. And, you know, I think that's a low probability, ironically because Facebook's data on its users is so good and its scale is so big, over 2 billion users, advertisers aren't going to give up that marketing channel.

So, you know, look, I think we said this earlier in the week, Lauren, this, too, shall pass for Facebook, but this nightmare is far from over. There's going to be a lot of questions to be answered in uncomfortable situations for the CEO.

BOLTON: Indeed, and it's also a business problem as we've talked about, too, in the sense that Facebook has to decide are we actually going to spend more money to get human engineers who cost money, who want vacations, who want personal time? But they probably need to hire a lot of people to make sure that these data infractions aren't repeated.

I want a message as well or let you know about this message that we got from Cambridge Analytica. The acting CEO says the data that had been obtained from Facebook was in line with Facebook's term of service and data protection laws. So that's a pretty -- and basically, Cambridge Analytica is saying, hey, listen, we didn't do anything wrong. We were following the map, if you like, that Facebook set out.

BASENESE: Right.

BOLTON: So that's going to be one of the conversations that's continued, to your point Lou, in D.C. and Mark Zuckerberg, is going to have to, I mean, the New York A.G. has started an investigation, the Massachusetts A.G., has started an investigation.

SIMONETTI: I know.

BOLTON: Senators Thune, Nelson, saying, listen, Mark Zuckerberg, you need to come here to D.C., you need to tell us --

SIMONETTI: And overseas there are investigations resume --

BOLTON: -- the U.K.

SIMONETTI: The Dow just fell about 200 points. And typically, Lou, we've seen the big tech companies, the so-called fang stocks recovered pretty quickly when there's a big sell-off. We're not seeing that this time around. What do you make of that?

BASENESE: I'm not too concern of that, I think this is the trickle-down effects from the regulatory threats that are facing Facebook, right? You've already had some Congress representatives calling in potentially other CEOs from tech companies to talk about regulating their data. I mean, this is just turning into a short-term debacle for Facebook, and it's spilling over into the larger tech stocks.

I think if you want to look for protection, you've got to go somewhere into the small and micro cap land that are largely insulated from all of this. But right now, the headline of the day is going to be the breach of user trust and, you know, there's an old ancient Jewish scholar that once said, be careful, your sins will find you out. And Facebook is learning that the hard way right now. Like Cambridge, Deirdre just share, the Cambridge CEO has pointing their finger at Facebook saying, hey, we didn't do anything wrong, you're the one that originally sent here gave us access to the user data. And it's going to be really hard to restore trust when users know that that was given so freely.

SIMONETTI: One story that just is not going away because it implicates regulation and other companies as well. Lou, Deirdre, thank you so much for your perspective today.

BASENESE: Thank you.

SIMONETTI: And that is it for me, but you can watch me every weekday, 5 a.m. Eastern on the Fox Business Network.

Now, Ashley Webster is in for Liz Claman. And Ashley?

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Yes. Here we go again.

SIMONETTI: Lock and load.

WEBSTER: TGIF.

SIMONETTI: There you go.

WEBSTER: But we had a big sell-off and here we are an hour to go before the bell rings that brings to the end, a very ugly week. Lauren Simonetti, thank you very much.

urn:contentItem:5W9R-PPN1-JCMN-Y153-00000-00Trump slams China's tech scene, says it doesn't have the capability of 'the geniuses in Silicon Valley that walk around in undershirts'2019-06-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:08ZLexisNexisTrump slams China's tech scene, says it doesn't have the capability of 'the geniuses in Silicon Valley that walk around in undershirts'Paige Leskin

Jun 10, 2019( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Associated Press/Evan Vucci Donald Trump[1] conducted an interview with CNBC[2] on Monday morning about the US-China tech cold war[3] and the battle for 5G dominance. During the interview, Trump argued[4] the US would beat out China because "they don't have nearly the capability of our geniuses in Silicon Valley that walk around in undershirts." Trump said that the US would be "leading very shortly" ahead of China in developing the 5G next-generation wireless network. Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories[5]. President Donald Trump defended the US's tech dominance on Monday and reasoned that China was no match for the "geniuses in Silicon Valley that walk around in undershirts."

Trump called in to CNBC's "Squawk Box" Monday morning to discuss a variety of issues, from tariffs in China and Mexico to big tech's regulation in the European Union. But Trump waved off any concerns that China would beat out the US in developing a next-generation 5G wireless network. "China, as great as they are — and they are great — they don't have nearly the capability of our geniuses in Silicon Valley that walk around in undershirts, and they're worth $2 billion apiece," Trump told CNBC[6]. "They don't have nearly the genius that these people have, and they practically admit it." Read more: The tech cold war: Everything that's happened in the new China-US tech conflict involving Google, Huawei, Apple, and Trump[7] The tech cold war between US and China[8] has maintained a fever pitch since the US barred American tech firms from working with Chinese companies like Huawei over concerns about state-sponsored spying and national security. Huawei told the US[9] that restricting its business would only harm US interests and cause the country to lag behind in deploying the 5G network. Most recently, Russia's largest network provider signed a deal with Huawei[10] to build 5G internet in 2019 and 2020. Nonetheless, Trump said Monday that the US would be "leading very shortly" in the race to implement 5G. The two countries have also duked it out by implementing heavy tariffs on each other's goods since March 2018. Last month, the US raised tariffs on Chinese goods to 25%[11]. Trump told CNBC on Monday that the hefty tariffs had successfully "decimated" China to help the US get the upper hand. Listen to the full interview Trump gave to CNBC here[12].NOW WATCH: This London handbag company has recycled 175 tons of fire hoses into fashion accessories[13]See Also: It looks like the US has abandoned any pretense that its war on Huawei is unrelated to the China trade talks[14]The tech cold war just got a lot more intense after Russia signed a deal to build 5G internet with Huawei[15]THE TECH COLD WAR: Everything that's happened in the new China-US tech conflict involving Google, Huawei, Apple, and Trump[16] SEE ALSO:Tesla employees are complaining that the company is trying to block urn:contentItem:5WJD-1VB1-F03R-N1T3-00000-00Trump slams tech firms at 'free speech' social media summit2019-07-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:08ZLexisNexisTrump slams tech firms at 'free speech' social media summit

Jul 12, 2019( Deutsche Welle World: http://www.dw.de/top-stories/world/s-1429 Delivered by Newstex) US President Trump has blamed big tech firms for gagging conservative voices at a summit of far-right online figures. At the same time, he applauded internet provocateurs for their "bad" social media behavior.US President Donald Trump on Thursday used a White House meeting of far-right social media provocateurs to once more criticize big tech firms such as Twitter and Facebook for what he sees as their unfair treatment of conservative voices."We're not going to be silenced," Trump said. "Big tech must not censor the voices."The US president has frequently claimed — without evidence — that major internet companies, including his favored communications outlet, Twitter, are biased against him, even suggesting that US regulators should sue them for anti-conservative leanings.He announced on Thursday that his administration would explore "all regulatory and legislative solutions to protect free speech and the free-speech rights of all Americans."

Read more: Is Facebook doing enough to combat fake news?'Genius, but bad'At the same time, Trump praised his guests at the "social media summit" — who did not include representatives of big tech firms — for their often extreme online behavior, while admitting that their presentations sometimes crossed the lines of accepted protocol."Some of you guys are out there — but even you should have a voice," he said. "The crap you think of is unbelievable. I mean it's genius — but it's bad."Trump said such presentations were a way of getting around what he claims is misinformation spread by mainstream media."You're challenging the media gatekeepers and corporate censors to bring the truth to the American people. ... You communicate directly with our citizens without going through the fake news filter," he said.Read more: The politics of deleting online hate speech No evidence Trump's claim that mainstream social media platforms have employed tactics to censor conservative political views has yet to be borne out by concrete evidence, and the companies themselves have denied any anti-conservative bias. His criticism also seems at odds with his frequent and outspoken use of Twitter. "Internet companies are not biased against any political ideology, and conservative voices, in particular, have used social media to great effect," the Internet Association, which represents Facebook, Google and dozens of other companies, said in a statement on Thursday.David Cicilline of Trump's own Republicans, who heads a House Judiciary subcommittee investigating the tech giants' market conduct, has also said he had found no evidence of their anti-conservative bias."I've never seen evidence of tech firm bias against conservatives," he said in a statement on Wednesday. "If someone wants to show me some empirical data, instead of some alt-right member's paranoid claims, I'd appreciate it."Although any censorship of mainstream conservative views has yet to be established, the big tech companies have been under recent pressure to ensure that their platforms are not used to disseminate extremist content. Twitter has banned hate speech targeting someone's race, gender and other categories, while Facebook has banned extremist figures such as Alex Jones of the conspiracy theory and fake news website Infowars and Louis Farrakhan of the African-American political and religious movement Nation of Islam.tj/ng (AP, Reuters)DW sends out a daily selection of the day's news and features. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60T8-1CH1-DYDW-70CP-00000-00Trump's latest attack on Section 230 is really about censoring speech2020-09-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:08ZLexisNexisTrump's latest attack on Section 230 is really about censoring speechNew Delhi, 2020-09-10 14:52:44

September 10 -- One aspect of the 2020 presidential campaign that isn't much discussed is the fact that both candidates want to end the internet as we know it. Both President Trump and Joe Biden have called for the end of Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, which protects tech companies in most cases when their users post something illegal on their platforms.


Trump brought the subject up today when a Twitter account with fewer than 200 followers posted an obviously doctored image of Senate Majority Mitch McConnell dressed up in Soviety military garb, with the caption reading "Moscow Mitch."
"Why does Twitter leave phony pictures like this up, but take down Republican/Conservative pictures and statements that are true?" the president wanted to know. "Mitch must fight back and repeal Section 230, immediately. Stop biased Big Tech before they stop you!"
He then tagged Republican senators Marsha Blackburn and Josh Hawley, who reliably step up to lodge baseless complaints about systematic bias against their party whenever called upon. (In fact, they introduced something called "the Online Freedom and Viewpoint Diversity Act" on Tuesday, the point of which seems to be to stop social networks from doing so much moderating.)
The reason Twitter (usually) leaves phony pictures like that up is that the United States permits its citizens to speak freely about politicians - even to say mean things about them. Repealing Section 230 would likely have no impact on the tweet in question, because the Twitter user's speech is protected under the First Amendment.
It might, however, make Twitter legally liable for what its users post - which would lead the company to remove more speech, not less. Whatever repealing Section 230 might achieve, it would not be what the president seems to want.
Anyway, all of this is well known to followers of the long-running Section 230 debates and seemingly impenetrable to everyone else. But if there's one important lesson from 2020, it's that long-running debates over expression can sometimes result in clumsy but decisive actions - ask TikTok! And so it's worth spending a few more minutes talking about what smarter people say ought to be done about Section 230.
As it so happens, there's a sharp new report today out on the subject. Paul Barrett at the NYU Stern Center for Business and Human Rights looks at the origins and evolution of Section 230, evaluates both partisan and nonpartisan critiques, and offers a handful of solutions.
To me there are two key takeaways from the report. One is that there are genuine, good-faith reasons to call for Section 230 reform, even though they're often drowned out by bad tweets that misunderstand the law. To me the one that lands the hardest is that Section 230 has allowed platforms to under-invest in content moderation in basically every dimension, and the cost of the resulting externalities has been borne by society at large.
Ellen P. Goodman, a law professor at Rutgers University specializing in information policy, approaches the problem from another angle. She suggests that Section 230 asks for too little - nothing, really - in return for the benefit it provides. "Lawmakers," she writes, "could use Section 230 as leverage to encourage platforms to adopt a broader set of responsibilities." A 2019 report Goodman co-authored for the Stigler Center for the Study of the Economy and the State at the University of Chicago's Booth School of Business urges transforming Section 230 into "a quid pro quo benefit." The idea is that platforms would have a choice: adopt additional duties related to content moderation or forgo some or all of the protections afforded by Section 230.
The Stigler Center report provides examples of quids that larger platforms could offer to receive the quo of continued Section 230 immunity. One, which has been considered in the U.K. as part of that country's debate over proposed online-harm legislation, would "require platform companies to ensure that their algorithms do not skew toward extreme and unreliable material to boost user engagement." Under a second, platforms would disclose data on what content is being promoted and to whom, on the process and policies of content moderation, and on advertising practices.
This approach continues to enable lots of speech on the internet - you could keep those Moscow Mitch tweets coming - while forcing companies to disclose what they're promoting. Recommendation algorithms are the core difference between the big tech platforms and the open web that they have largely supplanted, and the world has a vested interest in understanding how they work and what results from their suggestions. I don't care much about a bad video with 100 views. But I care very much about a bad video with 10 million.
So whose job will it be to pay attention to all this? Barrett's other suggestion is a kind of "digital regulatory agency" whose functions would mimic some combination of the Federal Trade Commission, the Federal Communications Commission, and similar agencies in other countries.
It envisions the digital regulatory body - whether governmental or industry-based - as requiring internet companies to clearly disclose their terms of service and how they are enforced, with the possibility of applying consumer protection laws if a platform fails to conform to its own rules. The TWG emphasizes that the new regulatory body would not seek to police content; it would impose disclosure requirements meant to improve indirectly the way content is handled. This is an important distinction, at least in the United States, because a regulator that tried to supervise content would run afoul of the First Amendment. [...]
In a paper written with Professor Goodman, Karen Kornbluh, who heads the Digital Innovation and Democracy Initiative at the German Marshall Fund of the United States, makes the case for a Digital Democracy Agency devoted significantly to transparency. "Drug and airline companies disclose things like ingredients, testing results, and flight data when there is an accident," Kornbluh and Goodman observe. "Platforms do not disclose, for example, the data they collect, the testing they do, how their algorithms order news feeds and recommendations, political ad information, or moderation rules and actions." That's a revealing comparison and one that should help guide reform efforts.
Nothing described here would really resolve the angry debate we have once or week or so in this country about a post that Facebook or Twitter or YouTube left up when they should have taken it down, or took down when they should have left it up. But it could pressure platforms to pay closer attention to what is going viral, what behaviors they are incentivizing, what harms all of that may be doing to the rest of us.
And over time, the agency's findings could help lawmakers craft more targeted reforms to Section 230 - which is to say, reforms that are less openly hostile to the idea of free speech. Moscow Mitch will continue to have to take his lumps. But the platforms - at last - will have to take theirs, too.
